pros: 401k, great salary, great benefits, and looks great on resume. Very challenging and will give you all of the knowledge needed to be successful if you hang in there and demand training as you will have to learn on your own.
cons:
Long hours, you know when you go in but not when you go home, management have no clue on how to build teams, develop others, treat others and are extremely under qualified for positions. If you are not in the "click" you won't be promoted or treated fairly. Very stressful atmosphere and no communication on vision. Every area functions on it's own versus having a work flow. This causes weekend work, missed schedules, no time for maintenance, and brings down the morale that is already low! HR is hands off from every aspect. Quality ruins the plant by making decisions based on if they like you or not versus status of the product. The plant manager is well aware of the situation but ignores it all.
Advice to Management
Clean house! Place people in positions they will thrive in so that the stress levels can be lowered. Put team building activities in place. Listen to employees and address concerns. Get involved with teams outside of your comfort zone.

review_title: Does Kraft - Heinz Company really care about their employees?
pros: decent pay for the neighborhood (rural Missouri) and that is the only reason why most people apply for this job. No one wants to make $8.50 an hour when they can make $16+.
cons:
Overtime is ridiculous because the turn over rate is so high, very little incentives for their employees (the might throw you a little pizza party every now and again), lacked in supporting is during Covid- 19 (made promises and then took them away), does express the help of EAP program and how resource it really is for an individual ( they briefly go over it in orientation to the point you honestly don't remember it and when they do explain it they don't explain the extent of its coverage). They care more about getting the pounds out the door than the safety of their employees. If something traumatic happens to you, make sure to be at work the next day like nothing happened.
Advice to Management
I believe that all Team Leaders, Supervisors, and Managers need to go through extensive training on how to manage a team. They way they talk to people is worse than some talk to a stray animal. We are humans and we should be treated as such. Management lacks majority of the skills to actually be a manager like communication, leadership, when to be a follower, when to deescalate a confrontation, how to motivate and drive their employees to be their best, understanding, and etc.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: I believe that all Team Leaders, Supervisors, and Managers need to go through extensive training on how to manage a team. They way they talk to people is worse than some talk to a stray animal. We are humans and we should be treated as such. Management lacks majority of the skills to actually be a manager like communication, leadership, when to be a follower, when to deescalate a confrontation, how to motivate and drive their employees to be their best, understanding, and etc.

review_title: Needed help before 3G, but 3G made it worse
pros:
a lot of great people to work with, camaraderie
many great brands and products 
nice office
cons:
nepotism among the Brazilians and 3G finance people 
merger purchase made the company over leveraged 
zero based budgeting meant fighting for necessities - for example a hundred dollar training for a new hire to replace the headcount that was cut 
constant headcount cuts 
difficult expectations and workload resulted in a revolving door of talent 
they got rid of annual merit reviews and turned it into a clandestine process
most benefits eroded over the years I worked there 
management by objectives (MBO) was a big carrot and bigger stick - huge bonuses that could be wiped out by poor sales or EBITA meant you could go the whole year performing well to receive nothing; MBO structure created infighting and promoted number manipulation, a large factor likely which lead to the SEC investigation
lack of innovation and reinvestment due to cost cutting focus, other CPGs were busy growing their brand and consumer base in better/fresher options, Kraft Heinz was busy mixing ketchup with mayonnaise. Other large CPG food companies's stock has grown steadily over past five years. 
General lack of strategic focus, too many initiatives that changed too frequently in order to distract from poor results

review_title: Company is changing...which is good news for new employees, but bad news for current employees
pros: Interesting work (in the right areas) and intelligent peers
cons:
The company is changing under its new leadership, with little practical benefits for current employees (unless you consider the opportunity to do the same work in a new Business Unit a benefit!). Company is now very focused on hiring externally and looking elsewhere for talent. It is very common to have someone new brought in and be less knowledgeable/effective than the person he or she is replacing, but many years older...I suspect this is b/c the people who are being brought in have stalled in their careers at their old companies...not exactly the type of talent you want to re-energize our company's turnaround! To that point, I have not seen an employee base been this marginalized in any of the previous companies I have worked at. There used to be clear career paths and room for growth in the company, but with all of the restructuring a significant # of employees were pushed laterally / demoted in responsibility with no upward mobility in sight. To cap it off, management consistently highlights "Clear Career Paths" in all of the transition meetings without actually mentioning any specifics...which always gets a good laugh in the side chats on Teams.
Advice to Management
Don't rely on the pandemic to keep people from leaving KHC, focus on helping talented people rise in the organization and show *concrete* ways for employees to develop their skills and without relying no vague US Zone presentations

pros: You'll own as much spend/responsibility as an entire team at any other CPG - just understand why this is. You won't get much appreciation or respect, you'll work long hours that only earn you more hours, etc. If you go in with a specific understanding of what you need to get out of the experience from an education and skill development standpoint, you can accomplish years of personal progression in a very short time. Just know it will probably hurt like hell.
cons:

pros:
- Great people from entry level to middle management.
- Challenging because there is almost zero guidance from upper management 
- Opportunity to advance faster than a normal company but this can also lead to under qualified in critical positions
cons:
- Never a consistent direction. The company changes its whole approach 2-3 times a year and expects employees to redo work to fit the new need. 
- Lack of long term view. Always focused on just the year at hand and never the next year to 5 years.
- Upper Management pretends to know everything and sets strategies without talking to middle or more junior positions. Majority of upper management is new to the company so clearly they lack any sort of historical information.
- You are expected to work constantly. PTO at KHC stands of Part Time Off or that's how it feels. 
- Severely understaffed with extremely inexperienced workers. It is not uncommon for a buyer 1 year out of college to manage $200 million in spend annually. 
- All managers are working managers but given the lack of staffing there is very little time to train, coach and develop their team.
Advice to Management
Stop working in a silo and ask your employees their opinions before you make drastic moves. At least all the people to have a voice. Also, prioritize your staff over everything else. I cannot even count the number of times upper management skips meetings because something "more important" came up then when a project doesn't get executed its the teams fault for not executing something that upper management needed to sign off on. Lastly, stop treating people as though they are a commodity and are completely expendable, you haven't been able to hire and hold anyone for 5 years, fix it!

pros: Competitive salary and benefits. Opportunities for advancement as the organization tries to fill mid-level openings from within in an effort to slow turnover and promote meritocracy. Lean staffing creates the opportunity to learn a lot, to accomplish anything you must work beyond your job description, it may also mean working below your intellectual capacity simply because there is no one else.
cons:
Growth targets are unrealistic in the cost cutting environment of Kraft Heinz. Too much time is spent answering why the targets aren't being achieved versus determining what is needed to achieve them. Little real progress is made, creating a pressure cooker environment and high turnover as talented people become discouraged, or are pushed out the door if their views do not align with the that of their manager/executives.

review_title: Terrible Experience as an Employee and Leader of a Business Division
pros: - empowers very junior people early on. This is a pro, but because it is poorly managed and monitored, turns into a liability for the company and other employees.
cons:
- Junior, inexperienced teams holding big titles and not really knowing what to do. Even the Brazilian senior management team is inexperienced with the complexity of the industry and business. C-level management group all worked together at a bankrupt, government owned railroad company in Brazil and think they can apply the same "recipe" into a much larger, more complex business in the most competitive market in the world - they are learning that they are wrong. 
- Human Resource globally and US is incompetent in hiring and retaining. The function is led by leaders with little experience in HR and extremely poor judgement. Their incompetence permeates the organization as they continue to promote and retain those similar to them in thinking and background. 
- Leaders spend lots of company resource in initiatives that last 3-6 months and then die away with the change of leadership or change of direction. Hard to look up to leaders with any credibility. No consistency. 
- Be wary when interviewing as the company hires irresponsibly: they like to "bring in good people" without the proper background for the role. Then offer no training or mentoring and quickly come to the conclusion "the person is not good enough". Don't expect a proper job description and proper internal communication, but do expect lots of internal competition, resulting in the same small group of "trusted" people being promoted and having more responsibilities.
Advice to Management
Find the company's strategic direction and follow through. Change the leftover legacy management team as soon as possible and hire competent, high caliber industry experts. Treat your people with dignity and respect and offer them visibility to their career.

review_title: A Turnaround or Whatever it is, Things are Getting Better
pros:
I believe you really need two separate reviews: 1) Kraft Heinz as a company and then 2) Your experience within your function. With that being said:

Kraft Heinz:
- We're experiencing the so called "turn around" at the moment and things are looking fairly optimistic. Leadership changes are encouraging and internal engagement is being taken very seriously compared to virtually nothing in the past when I was hired. Keep veering away from the 3G culture - it's a failed concept and holds a negative perception externally. 
- This is a mega food company - fifth largest in the world. It carries weight and you take pride seeing our brands all around in the world and in some 97% of households.
- Kraft Heinz is an incredibly diverse organization from Chicago to London, Melbourne to Shanghai, and everywhere in between. I appreciate this, and the Diversity & Inclusion efforts of this company are world-class. I've made friendship with colleagues from all around the world!

My Function:
- Amazing leadership and ability to grow if you prove yourself. Somewhat controversial in the company as a whole, but "Meritocracy" is actually taken seriously in my area of the business - in my view.
- You're told "thank you" by senior leaders - and more importantly they are accessible whenever you need them. Amazing for a Fortune 500 company.
- Compensation is very competitive and I'm proud to be paid not just market rate, but even a little higher compared to external peers.
cons:
I believe you really need two separate reviews: 1) Kraft Heinz as a company and then 2) Your experience within your function. With that being said:

Kraft Heinz: 
- Sometimes it feels like a really new startup company, despite being 150 years old. Frustrating, but *sometimes* thrilling as you can sort of steer the ship however you believe is right for the business.
- Kraft Heinz is INCREDIBLY competitive. Seriously. I write this as a "Con" because it sometimes can get a little divisive as everyone is trying to climb towards the top or try and take credit for your idea - or even squash it outright.
- A perfect segway into this..... It is a super young company. No, really. Everywhere you look there's under 30 employees at every corner. While this isn't a full out "Con" I think it speaks to the gutting of senior/seasoned positions at the time of the merger in 2015, especially legacy Kraft folks from Chicago.
- I would only "recommend to a friend" if they're up for a big challenge. Be ready for a "do WAY more with WAY less" mentality and prep to work a few jobs just yourself. 
- 3G is the "parent" owner and you have to live with that. At the end of the day, it's not necessarily an American company, BUT I am inspired by the thousands of US jobs provided both corporate and across our plants - particularly in rural areas. At the end of the day, Kraft, Heinz, and many of our classic brands are still "iconic American" but the $$ goes to Brazilians. 

My Function:
- There's somewhat a lack of diversity, but it's being worked on and has been transparently addressed.

pros: This is a mixed review because I love the company and love the team. I had a great time while performing my job. Immediate team was great. They give you the sales tools you need to do your job and provide great support on those. They promote from within before looking outside. Benefits are good.
cons:
No service level agreements in corporate so emails and requests can go unanswered for an eternity. No urgency. Leadership is confusing at best. I have seen them laying off good people while retaining others who didn't even know how to send an email when they were hired. Constant requiring training and quizzes on ethics. Huge splash across Laptop DO THE RIGHT THING.... Looks awesome at airports when on way to see customers. Looks the other way when it comes to bullying even though policy says they do not. Some managers have extremely low emotional IQ yet they are still promoted. Females are significantly underpaid. No raises for years. Change bonus criteria constantly mid-earning. No budget for office supplies or reimbursement for internet or utilities (they require you manage their frozen and refrigerated sample products) so you will be responsible for the cost of the electricity to support a freezer, or refrigerator or both. The worst communication from corporate that I have ever encountered in all the companies I have worked for. Be prepared to chase people around for answers. If in the field, you will have little no no way to understanding who is in what job responsibility at corporate. They have this system called Meritocracy which sounds good on paper, but has resulted in inexperienced people in charge of important functions failing the field because it appears they are training themselves on the job and don't know what they are truly doing. Be prepared for ZBB .. Zero Balance Budgeting.... no office supplies. You pay for your own...including printer ink. Be prepared for ridiculous amount of admin.
Advice to Management
Start considering what is best for the company instead of "what makes the most sense"....which, in reality...doesn't, when it comes to common sense. Don't worry about saving that $7.00 a month on office supplies over capturing new business. Stop with so many ethics training quizzes. If you think they are dishonest, don't hire them. Let the sales team sell. Back off the administrative build up. Not only are they having to perform the task, they have to learn how to build these reports and presentations to the specific format you are requesting. There are many sales reps who are tech savvy disasters and spend a whole day melting down before they can even get the courage to attempt these reports. Please understand that these reports are most likely fiction as your Salesforce reporting is not always accurate. It often has disconnects within the accounting. If you want your customers to support KHC, do a better job supporting them. I would suggest better marketing research when coming up with new products. We sold our hearts out be saw them as the flops they were coming out of the gate. Get better programmers for Salesforce. There's a ton of repetitive required entries within each landing page. Overhaul the product lists and use standardized naming so people aren't having to take 5 to 20 minutes to find one product number. There are many gaping inefficiencies.
Helpful (9

Helpful (1

review_title: Grueling Culture with No Change in Sight
pros: The salary is competitive if you speak up and demand to be paid equal to your peers. Kraft is infamous for its "Meritocracy" culture which essentially means promoted to a higher position but paid less than what that position is typically paid. There are still great people here which is what has kept me here. Great brands as well.
cons:
The SLT talks a big game regarding change and employee wellness but ultimately falls short. The expectations from a bonus perspective are unrealistic. 50% bonus targets, but what management doesn't tell you is that is multiplied by how the total company does, so i have made 100% of my personal bonus, which will be multiplied by a 30% and ultimate will get a regular sized bonus. The workload expected does not warrant average bonuses. Employees are shamed if they leave before 6pm. Health and Wellness isn't actually a concern despite the weekly emails from HR reminding us to de-stress. What would help employees de-stress is a culture that discourages managers to cancel employees Dr appts, workout classes, put on 7am regular meetings.
Advice to Management
Stop talking about change and actually do it before everyone quits. We have a 15% retention issue which is higher than the industry average for a reason. No one is happy with the current culture. Resource our teams appropriately, coach new managers and outside hires, don't set people up for failure. Give us a reason to stay at KHC.

No one is happy with the current culture. Resource our teams appropriately, coach new managers and outside hires, don't set people up for failure. Give us a reason to stay at KHC.

review_title: They care more about cutting costs than employees
pros:
Pay is well. 

Lots of opportunities to learn programs like Lean Manufacturing and other similar initiatives.
cons:
Money hungry. They’re always cutting costs. Only allowed 5 boxes a paper a month for an entire plant. 
Poor leadership. Company leaders are out of touch with what it takes to run a factory. More concerned with zero budget billing than actually producing quality product. 
High turnover rate. Corporate office is always moving people around, new hires are typically right out of college and you have to start projects over. 
Everything is outsourced. From HR to production planning, to truck assignments, everything is outsourced through India or contractors to cut costs. They fired an entire department and had them rehired at the contractor for less pay, that’s how little they care for employees.

pros: Benefits are okay even tho no annual small raise.
cons:
Let's be honest. Everyone is all about titles in R&D and some of the best developers have left to work at other companies where they'll be appreciated. Promote people to Manager and they walk around still with the stank look that they don't want to be there. Walk down the hall, people don't say hello but will send an email when they need you to do something for them. Hold a panel about careers and owning your career in the company and they chose leaders who don't know what their direct reports are doing and leaders who don't even speak to junior developers or new people when walking down the hall – talk about reasons why engagement is down and 2-3 developers are leaving each week. HR isn't the best at being supportive – you never see them when they are in the office and don't sit in on department meetings. It's not even worth driving to feel worthless and what you're doing doesn't matter. Some BUs promote developers straight out of school within the FIRST YEAR and they have NO EXPERIENCE and PROFESSIONALISM which reflects their managers. Try to move to a different function and bitter managers block you. People come in late and leave as soon as their managers who get in early leave. Managers have no professionalism – swearing in the office and talking about others out loud on conference calls or telling junior developers information they shouldn't. NO. CONFIDENTIALITY. NO. PROFESSIONALISM. No true timeline or model to promotions and a career @KHC. Actually offering folks more money and promotion when they give a two weeks notice. It's a sick feeling working somewhere for 8 hours with people who don't play as a team but only for themselves and that's across the board.
Advice to Management
Please throw out everyone with an Associate Director position title and put people in place who are willing to mentor their direct reports and learn with them. Stop bringing in "talent" from other states just to ensure they stay with the company because you provided relocation stipulations for >3 years. Ask your Managers, Sr. Managers, Leads, Associate Directors, and Directors what they would do if their best developers left the company (it's already happened and it's showing they don't know basic fundamentals). Get rid of Inspiration Rooms and bring back Townhalls with relevant industry information. Stop walking around being COMFORTABLE – your quality people are leaving the company and not ONE leader has said anything or HR. BE MORE TRANSPARENT about what's going on and tell your leaders to be more personable.

pros: Opportunity to learn more in 1-2 years than you would in 5-10 years at another company if you are willing to sacrifice your personal life, relationships, and health for that duration. Work with a lot of very talented people that care about what they do. Compensation is good if you can hit your bonus target 100% which is rare.
cons:
No onboarding, job training, or continued development. New hires are expected to jump in immediately without any provided tools, training, or equipment. Employees are often without basic equipment such as second monitors and docking stations that improve efficiency. Having a desk can be a privilege. Employees have gone weeks or even months without a dedicated work space. Forget about any work life balance as 11 & 12 hour days are the new norm. Too many meetings leave employees scrambling to catch up on actual “work” on the weekends. Leaving your desk for lunch is a luxury and only reserved for the occasional Friday or birthday celebration. High turnover results in inexperienced employees being promoted to managerial roles without proper training and brand strategies change every few months making it impossible to execute strong campaigns. Roles are often “downgraded” to cut costs leaving too much responsibility with inexperienced employees. No trust with cross-functional teams due to competing bonus targets, making it near impossible to work together to accomplish what is best for the business. There are constant “fire drills” that come up due to management’s lack of organization and delegation which make for a very high stress environment.
Advice to Management
Establish a culture that sets boundaries that allow for more work-life balance. Burnout and turnover is too high and employees do not feel respected.

Kraft Heinz advertises meritocracy, but the opportunities to move across teams and to get promoted varies by team, manager, and HRBP. There is no consistency across what Kraft Heinz stands for. They do not treat all employees equally when it comes to their career growth.

HR processes are very slow. You will wait for your promotion or new role for months if you're just unlucky enough to be on a team or have an HRBP that is passive.
Advice to Management
Fix the way you advertise career growth - if meritocracy is true, then promote equally across teams and BUs when people work hard.
Helpful (5
advice_to_mgmt: Fix the way you advertise career growth - if meritocracy is true, then promote equally across teams and BUs when people work hard.

review_title: Never imagined it could be this bad
pros:
Good portfolio of brands even though many are declining in value

Base pay is still above average but lack of annual merit increase and lower (sometime no) bonus payout means total compensation lags industry
cons:
Meritocracy is a code word for we promoted you because the person who had the position left the company. 

Really screwed up priorities. Salespeople spend 80% of their time on calls with finance. Headquarter teams prioritize ritual internal meetings (MPRs, etc) over work that supports our customers. Millions wasted on a retail sales team that occasionally gets displays in third tier accounts. Lots of pictures to make everyone feel good but not driving the business and most of open sales roles are to fill vacancies on this high turnover team.

Hiring people with no experience is a common con for many companies but it’s a common occurrence at KHC particularly for high profile headquarter jobs. We’re hiring smart people with promises of bonuses and rapid advancement. 

KHC and Wall Street have realized that our brands have lost $Bs due to lack of investment but the company is slow to realize the same could be said for the people. Morale and engagement are at an all time low and many senior managers lack experience to lead.
Advice to Management
Miguel please accelerate the seismic change that has to take place. Get rid of the 3Gers and senior leadership that has run this company into the ground. Focus less on recruiting future talent - most of them leave within 2-3 years. Invest in KHC legacy employees to rebuild the company.

pros: Turnover is high, no one wants to work for the company, so you can grow in your career extremely fast.
cons:
If you work in a manufacturing facility you work 10-12 hours everyday, I've worked up to 16 hour days before. This includes Monday- Monday, that's right, often times 7 days a week. No compensation for working more hours, while your manager has every weekend off. 

They are an unethical company overall. They glorify people who do whatever it takes to get numbers. That means no regard for food safety, people, or giving your team the resources to get the job done. It is all about making cuts and never about seeing the bigger picture. When I started the stock was $82 per share and now it is $32.07, so none of these measures have been successful and they have not done anything to make the company culture better. 

Lastly, when I put my two weeks in they asked me not to come back and did not pay out my two weeks or my vacation time. I had already worked two days of that pay period.

Their 401K match is 100% to 2.5%, then they match 50% up to 6%, very low compared to all the other companies I interviewed with and then took a different job at. Health insurance is not great, and no employee perks. 

When employees who had been working at the company for 40 years retire HR did not even give them a thank you card for their dedication. The HR team in Massillon would pick and choose who and they wanted to enforce their policies on.
Advice to Management
Sell the company.

pros: I love working there I learn new stuff all the time very great place to be
cons:
Great people great hours
Helpfu

pros: Great introductory job in CPG industry
cons:
If you have worked in CPG before, don’t bother. They do everything backwards and lie about programming. Your boss will tell you that your store needs a second bacon rack bc it’s a corporate program. You ask to see the email/memo from the store’s corporate office so you can share with your store managers. Your manager says “I don’t have anything like that, just get it up bc that’s what our company wants”. They obviously lied about it and want to brag to their superiors about how they up-sold bacon racks.

There’s the ISPs which services the stores and there’s the customer team that works on programming. Both have different goals and the customer team exports a lot of their work on the ISPs. Then a couple of my fellow ISPs were reported to our managers claiming they weren’t executing, but in fact the ISPs WERE EXECUTING, provided photos and other evidence. The customer team was actively sabotaging the ISPs and nothing was done about it. Every time the customer team screws up (which is frequent), they’ll blame the ISPs and the ISP managers take the side of the customer team! 

Chicago US Sales people are a joke. You spend more time doing ice breakers and putting together cardboard displays than you learn about your benefits and other important issues when you’re on-boarding. “Just go to the website” is a very common term when you have any issues or “Just send a ticket”. IT will fix any insignificant problem you have, but don’t count on them addressing any major issues. The recruiters and KH HR BOTH told me during interviews that the bonus is supposed to be easy to achieve as an extra perk to retain top talent. Then the news came out about how KHC is being federally investigated for missing millions of dollars and all of a sudden, they changed our goals for our bonuses and surprise surprise they became much more difficult. One component was store performance, you could dominate a store but if no one buys your product you get penalized! They measure just about every goal via your iPad, but the programs they use are NOTORIOUS for not being accurate with out of date data/freezing up/not having any data at all/etc. With all those facts along with that 3G cuts everything it sees, it’s no secret that they actively work against you in regards to reaching your bonus.

Managers throughout the country, especially the Midwest are quitting, ISPs who are experienced sales professionals quit constantly bc they know more than their managers and the managers retaliate with busy work or they’ll “promote you” aka ship you off to another state/division of the company. Absolutely toxic environment, a bunch of yes people that think every idea is great with nobody questioning the questionable ideas out of fear of retaliation. Be careful of HR, there’s plenty of loyalty there and they’ll sell you out. 

Meritocracy is a HUGE MYTH! They promote boot lickers. A little over 40 of us on-boarded the same time and we’re all told we’d be in different positions 9-12 months IF we executed in our stores. We hit the ground running and killed it and NOTHING. They lied to fill out their sales force. It was “well you executed 95% and we are looking for 100%”, they nitpick to justify keeping you in sales. And they never mention that you’ll most likely have to relocate if you wanna move up. Over half of the 40+ ISPs have quit.

My manager had the nerve to say I was unprofessional bc I got upset with his lack of support, yet every ride with we had, he constantly would objectify women in my stores. 

If you’re fresh out of college, the comp package is great. 

If you’ve ever worked in CPG, keep looking, there’s so many better companies out there that know what they’re doing.

Here’s some other interesting info...
After I quit, it took them a week to send someone to pick up my car and of course they had the wrong car information. The guy who was picking it up was on a tight schedule to get home and he had to wait two hours for the issue to be corrected. I felt so sorry for the guy, but wasn’t surprised bc that’s KHC in a nutshell. They screw up with no accountability and the little people get screwed.

Also, I’ve been gone for several months now and I’m still receiving coupons and POS in the mail. This is supposed to be one of the largest food companies in the world and they DO NOT have their act together.
Advice to Management
Tear it all down and rebuild, but that’s not your style.
Helpful (14
advice_to_mgmt: Tear it all down and rebuild, but that’s not your style.

review_title: Avoid if you want to have a normal life
pros:
- View from Aon center can’t be beat, world class
- Cool work location
- There are still a lot of talented, good people across the org willing to go outside the rules and work as a team. Outside of work, most people except the truly brainwashed ones understand it’s Crazy Town.
- The first year after they acquire a new company, the bonus is great.
- You will get the opportunity to gain scope and responsibilities 10 years earlier than other companies, without any of the support, pay, and ability to succeed.
- At least in their words but not actions or deeds, they aren’t wrong about what’s needed to course correct the food industry since the golden age has passed.
- Your doctor won't question why you are asking for anti-anxiety meds when you tell them where you work
cons:
- Pretty much everything else
- Destroyed 2 iconic, dynamic, and talent driven companies in less than 5 years.
- Entire 3G philosophy is based on some corny “business” book “how to double your profits in six months or less”, that’s belongs in the check-out lane of the grocery store. 
- Management is incompetent and complete scam artists. Rule by arrogance and brute force to cover up ignorance.
- If you need someone from another team’s help on something and it contradicts with their MBO, kiss any help bye-bye. Even if it leads to a negative result for the company at large.
- Groups have completely contradicting MBOs, leading to chaos and waste on a mass scale…ironic
- You will be penalized for god forbid trying to personalize your desk environment with more than 2 personal items and trying to trick yourself that you aren't working in a corporate sweat shop.
- Bring your own office supplies and IT equipment. 
- Training is a complete joke and you will be asked to complete it in an absurd amount of time on top of everything else you are doing rendering it useless.
- Anything you actually accomplish in spite of the dysfunctional environment will constantly either be ignored by idiotic management, or overshadowed by some new complete disaster in another department that seems like you hear about in a weekly basis
- At the end of large meetings, you will be required to do this laughable “battle cry” chant that will make you feel either like you are at a high school pep rally, or the local hitler youth rally.
- If 3G didn’t take over the legacy Kraft Foods glassdoor account and flood the page with fake 5 star reviews… the score would probably be in the 1’s
- You will constantly be pressured to do unethical things to get ahead. Those that do or are on the fast track b/c they are young are typically rewarded after doing one thing well.
- People across the organization way out of depth in their responsibilities with little experience or perspective.
- No employee development, no merit raises, bonus and targets are usually completely unreachable.
- You may finally truly grasp the concept of Hell
Advice to Management
- Looks like Buffet finally smelled the rot and is cleaning house, but round all the 3G sociopaths and send them packing.
- Stop reveling in being the biggest cheapskate around to your employees. They aren’t stupid
- Stop actively dis-qualifying experienced talent, pushing them all out got you into the hole you are today.
- Don’t celebrate the achievements of the now departing executives. This is a mockery of the complete disaster they have been. Forcing employees to film thank you videos for one of the worst food industry CEOs in living memory is a complete joke

review_title: Great Pay/Benefits but A lot of discrimination
pros: Great Pay for Team Leads, easy job for laborers and a lot of people who will help support you. A lot of great benefits, 2 weeks vacations after your first month of being with the company. A lot of room for promotions!
cons:
Seniority is an issue, they value how long you have been there more than actual performance. They have three different shifts, 1st shift being 7a-3:30, 2nd shift 3p-11:30p and 3rd shift 11p-7:30, to which they will stick you on a shift depending on when you were hired, not if you are good at your job or not. A lot of discrimination. The majority of individuals hired by Kraft in Garland are African Americans, management is mostly made up of White Americans, and they hire a bunch of Burmese Asians that don't speak English (which causes a lot of bottlenecks). It boils down to if the African Americans don't like you, they will call you a racist and go to HR with false information to purposely get you moved or fired. The people who can vouch for you don't ever get questioned or don't speak English, so HR automatically believes what they hear and give the liars what they want. I've even had a African American Line Lead tell me that I was received complains against, and then told me that they didn't want to work with me because of my Hispanic background and age, but never took the situation to HR. That same Lead also gets her "favorites" good high paying leadership positions and let's them sit in the coordinators office, sometimes even moving Team Leads from their designated shift (for example 2nd shift) and move them to 3rd shift without asking so her favorites can stay with her and she can protect them. New Plant Manager is extremely out of touch, even going as far as telling us to fire an entire line (40+ employees) instead of re-training.
Advice to Management
Don't be scared of the "racist" threats. Have a fly on the wall in each line, and you will see the amount of discrimination your people are going through. You might, in case, find out that some of the people who are complaining are usually either lazy, disappear of the line (and steal time) or take 1 hour breaks.

review_title: Toxic Culture + Fake Positive Reviews from HR
pros: Job provides a salary and benefits, which is better than being unemployed (maybe)
cons:
Kraft Heinz does not care about their people in the slightest. All of their mission/values are strictly just to have something posted on the website and something to share with stockholders. They are not adhered to whatsoever. Each employee is just a number, and the company is way too cheap to care about the happiness/satisfaction of their employees. The company is way too focused on cost cutting and savings, at the expense of quality of both product and work environment which is a leading factor in the extremely high turnover rate. 

HR ignores serious concerns regarding employee safety because they are too busy trying to save money and meet their "go get" given to them by the ZBB team. 
Priority isn't actually given to internal employees for open positions, despite being told that they love to promote from within. HR/Recruiting is extremely unresponsive and comes across as very stuck up and rude. This is detrimental as Kraft does not do inflation based or merit based raises often if ever - the only way to get a raise is to get a promotion. This becomes extremely difficult when many positions are frozen/never filled due to budget.

The day I quit, I instantly felt so relieved. I would never recommend that anyone works here. The turnover rate is horrible, the pay seems great at first but unless if you're regularly being promoted (difficult in light of constant hiring freezes) you will never get a raise even if you overdeliver on your MBOs. This company will definitely not last if it continues on the way it has been going since the merger.

Also, don't be fooled by the bonus structure. It sounds great but is completely dependent on company performance. It's completely possible to get 100% on your MBOs and still receive a $0 bonus if the company multiplier isn't there. This didn't happen in 2019, but did in 2018 and probably will happen again given how tight money is at Kraft.
Advice to Management
Care about your employees. Stop being so cost cutting/savings focused because it's counterproductive and actually hurting numbers. You have to invest in both people and innovation. The 100M being spent investing in people in 2019 that was advertised never seemed to come through and it actually felt like the people numbers were cut in light of the slashed shares/SEC investigation.

pros:
1. Extremely challenging environment - great minds to interact and work with
2. Give you ownership with your tasks and responsibilities
3. Performance and bonus is tied directly to P&L
4. Lots of opportunities to escalate career
5. Outside your comfort zone
cons:
1. Poor resource allocation. Zero based budgeting done wrong. They'll give you the worst tools (laptops/ softwares) to do your task. An hour long task could take 5-6 hours since no serious planning has gone to it. Had to use my personal device. 
2. No matter where you fall in the employment scale, it's cut-throat, and you're looked upon as a COG and not a human. So there is very little investment on their end for your long term growth at least not for the first year or so. The company is run by finance brains (3G capital - go figure) therefore operations are run as a means to an end and not as a focus to be a well operating machine. They throw smart people at the problem and the smart people due to lack of time (short of resources) come up with short term solutions to fundamentally broken systems/ problems. At the end of the day, the focus isn't to have the healthiest product at the best price, it's to push out anything edible at the lowest cost. (compare KHC to Nestle, Unilever, or Kellogg). Long story short, the higher up you are the less job security you should expect - not because of performance, but because of they run the company based on delivering Quarterly numbers. Opposite of how Amazon runs it's business (its important to compare the two because they both claim to use Zero Based Accounting but the later actually knows how to leverage it).
Advice to Management
1. Invest intelligently on computational tools. You could actually leverage the time value of your employees.
2. Zero Based Budgeting is great, only if you know how to budget for operations. You're manufacturing facilities and warehousing is run so poorly that it's embarrassing to watch. Fundamentals to evaluate operations are Performance, Availability, and Quality. Budgeting based on last years financials (typical Wall Street move) doesn't get you lowered operating expenses. It creates loss in revenue caused by backlog. I understand being in the ring of fire constantly but its important to take a step back and evaluate a longer term solution. Roll out something like TPM across all factories and watch the company make a quantum leap in terms of sustained profitability. Then go after companies like Unilever. Randomly visit 4 of your factories and DCs and then do the same for Unilever in North America and you'll see what I am talking about. 
3. Please revisit all Demand Planners, check their performance in detail and see how far away from any logic or strategy is used to make predictions. It creates a ripple effect of poor decisions all the way up to customer delivery. Hate to say it, invest in machine learning (I think Genpact is the new supplier) and revisit the algorithms used in each categories. Before that recategorize products based on some consistent business logic rather than what sounds good or what Kraft and Heinz have done in the past. You can't blame category managers for their performance if you don't give them the tools to do a good job. It's not 2005, It's 2019, act accordingly. 
4. Revisit ALL distribution routes and hubs. There is money sitting on plane sight. 
5. Going back to it all - If you truly want to create the "World's Best Food Company" then you need to sacrifice a couple of quarters of managing "Analyst's Expectations" and mange your employee's needs, and your customers wants. Also the best food company sells the best food, not sugar and meat laced carcinogens that's impacting customers in a negative way - just a thought, might not be your strategy. Then change your mission statement to "Be a company that delivers the best value food". I expect more from Brazilians. 
6. You have everything in your power to turn this business around. Listen to what the employees are trying to say and leverage their talent effectively. This is not a burger king (another poorly run 3G business) or a retail or an alcoholic beverage company - please stop copy pasting business strategy across all business. If your focus is to produce food with inelastic demand - then good, stay there, but look into your OEE for manufacturing facilities and roll out an aggressive 3 year TPM plan Brazilian style instead of blindly chopping of unprofitable footprint - its unprofitable not due to demand but due to poor PCA (refer to fundamentals). Focus internally for at least 2 years before trying to acquire anything. Your competitors are selling the same economic good with a higher quality and with healthier alternatives. Cutting operational units, labor, to reduce your operating expense doesn't make anything better. Look at your inventory numbers/ ratios since the take over. Can't really hide behind those right? It would be great if you ran it like a company of people for people rather than a company of COGS for Market Share. You're blessed with talent and have great momentum going for you. Good luck! Hope this helps, and thank you for the great opportunity (I mean it).
Helpful (36)

Thank you for your thoughtful comments. I am glad to see that you had a positive experience while you were here. You have brought up some excellent points. I have shared this with the leadership team. Best of luck to you. - Elizabet

pros: This is a company that bases bonuses and promotions based on merit. But, that strategy is fraught with challenges...
cons:
...by promoting based on a single success versus a series of successes. I'm seeing this a lot in the Marketing and Supply Chain organization. Regardless of success, experience can only be gained by time. And, because of the meritocracy aspect, KHC pays a premium for less experience in Supply Chain and likely Marketing. These 20-somethings will not have many options elsewhere and will likely take pay cuts and title demotions--because a few wins does not translate into demonstration of consistent winning.
Advice to Management
Merit increases is an expectation in the U.S. job market. Upon learning that a colleague has only received 1 merit increase in 4 years, I am incredibly disappointed that this was not fully disclosed. And, it's tremendously disrespectful to employees and runs counter to respecting the value of employees. Why does KHC think it's okay to raise prices on their products but not provide merit increases to their employees. This is one surefire way to reduce your employees ability to maintain their quality of life and yet expect them to promote the price increases. The 3G cost cutting method is a failure. If this company was realistic in their quest for success, every 3G employee should be removed and replaced with those who know what they're doing, understand the balance between cost and revenue, and truly want to see the company succeed.
Helpfu

review_title: Mechanical departments that are run by the good ol' boys club
pros: This is a fantastic place to come if all you need is Industrial Experience to put on your resume.
cons:
Every mechanical department is run by a good ol' boys club. The management team is too arrogant and lazy to actually lead, so they let the senior mechanics run the shows. Whatever makes it so senior management doesn't have to leave their offices. The senior mechanics are all close to retirement and just want to ride the sinking ship that is Kraft Heinz to the end with no worries. So, if you are just starting out with your career and need growth and development, you will not get it from them. If you ask management to help you, they will always side with the good ol' boys, especially if it means they don't actually have to work.

Everything is falling apart. Everything is broken. You will not be allowed to fix anything. You will spend your days as an HVAC mechanic reading books and pretending to look busy.

The culture here is extremely toxic. You will hate your job. You will hate the management. You will hate the Union. The only thing worth being here for is the people.

All this place is good for is to make your resume look good. By 2020, the place will close or be sold. Don't waste your time coming here in hopes of a career. The ol' boys will make sure you don't grow. Just use this place make money, suck out of it what you can and leave.

review_title: Get in and get out (Beware "Fake" HR Postings)
pros: There is comradery is misery; your average employee is incredible. They're all supportive, take the time to listen, and really want the best for each other. There are some leaders in the company that are so easy to believe in and follow into the dark (Positive), but they all exist below what’s called the Zone Presidents level, and they're quickly leaving. Some of the BIGGEST stalwarts in the CPG industry (be it in Marketing, or Category Leadership, Sales, or otherwise) have been running for the exits. The plan isn't healthy, the innovation isn't innovation, and the people in charge mainly got there due to nepotism (no need to look further than Hees' resume and how he was connected to get to the roles he got to; his results speak for themselves and the results are terrible).
cons:
BEWARE OF SOME OF THESE REVIEWS. EVEN I WAS ASKED BY HR TO WRITE A POSITIVE REVIEW TO INCREASE THE RATING OF THE COMPANY ON GLASSDOOR. JUST TAKE HEED WITH ALL REVIEWS

No amount of team comradery will get you through the company bureaucracy. The company likes to entice people to join by over-paying, but to get an advancement/promotion while in the company, they will undercut you as much as possible. In fact, it's in line with their Zero-Based Budgeting policies. For example, if there's an open role and as a hiring manager you have already identified the appropriate candidate to fill the role internally, we will not hire that person for a minimum 6 - 8 weeks to save on budget. In the grand scheme of things, is this really fair to the surrounding team that needs to pick up the slack? Does the savings really make a tangible difference?
Furthermore, there are teams that cook their numbers to seem more beneficial than the realized success actually is (ask them about ISP). 
And if that wasn't enough, I wish I could share some of the several videos where our CEO dodges questions about long term strategy, mainly because he is benchmarked historically on in-year results. Only for the first time ever are his goals overtly stated as more than one year long and that's this year (2019). It's a sad state of affairs. I'm not sure 3G was ready to put the "good boys' club" to bed [see: Hees', again].
Advice to Management
I hope that some of these examples illuminate what it means to work at KraftHeinz and not the musings of a disgruntled employee. If I'm being honest, I've learned a lot in role, made some amazing friendships, and have recently been offered a promotion, that I will turn down because of some of the reasons I've listed above, all while in a hiring freeze. HOWEVER, the company is best to get on the resume, build as best you can while you're here, and then leave. There's a reason that in some groups, employee turnover is nearing 90% and that there are HR goals to retain employees (even unsatisfactory ones). Unfortunately for those in HR, they're hindered by policies that are unjust and they can't keep people even if they really wanted to. The biggest things the company can do right now to turn around, in my perspective (representative of many others), is to first put the 'human' back in Human Resources; I am a number to them. Literally. Second, they really need to take a look in the mirror around their strategy long-term. The current playbook is Acquire [a company], Gut [all costs], and repeat. Organic growth is not part of the strategy because investment is not part of the strategy. It's a travesty because I love so many of the brands. They've just made it near impossible to do business with, and for, them.

pros: Coworkers who are nice for the most part

This is the most hostile, toxic environment I've ever worked in. Corporate only cares about cutting costs and does not care about their employees at all. The employees are treated unfairly and are made to feel like garbage. They work you to death and then write you up if you can't keep up. There are many, many long time employees who are loyal and dedicated but feel like they are being taken advantage of by management. There are zero employee perks left. The supervisors base their decisions on whether they like you or not and what race or gender and age you are. They only want young, attractive white "poster" employees. If you don't fit that criteria, you will never be successful in this company. There is rampant preferential treatment based on color, race, gender and job function. If you are the right "type" you can run the show. If you aren't then you are doomed to fail. They allow certain job functions (mechanics) do whatever they want.

Stop being racist. Stop playing favorites. Pay attention to what your employees are telling you is happening.

Thanks for your note. This feedback is deeply concerning as an organization and we take these matters very seriously.

pros:

3) As one of the largest food companies, there are a ton of opportunities within this one office. Easy to move to a different function, with and without prior experience in the area (as long as you've demonstrated the ability and eagerness to learn)

pros:
- Decent compensation plans
- Smart, driven people
cons:
In no particular order:

- The culture? Cut costs. That's about it. You're just a cog in the machine, competing with the other cogs to keep turning. The result is a toxic environment that provides little enrichment to the bright people that make their way into and right back out of their offices.

- Employees are provided with the absolute minimum to do their jobs, even in corporate locations. Corporate employees were provided a laptop and literally nothing else, not even a separate keyboard and mouse to use at their workstations.

- Corporate offices are completely open in format, disallow more than three personal items in your space at any given time, and can get decidedly noisy.

- HR was minimally responsive to concerns when they were raised. Many just give up trying and suffer with their circumstances... or quit.

- Healthcare plans are pretty dismal by corporate standards. 

- Turnover is frequent. There are a lot of inexperienced folks in senior positions. This is not a complaint at all about those people; they are great, but institutional knowledge is rare.
Advice to Management
Define a real culture. Implement 360 degree reviews. Emphasize the importance of valuing your employees as more than a means to an end.

review_title: Always Challenging and Exciting, Where Only The Best Thrive
pros:
--Fast-paced culture; there's never a lull in the day and you blink and the day has gone past.
--Amazing downtown location, with floors between 72-76 of the Aon Center
--Room for international growth with Zones HQs in London, Toronto, Singapore, Amsterdam and Sao Paulo
--Challenging, Rewarding work. You are given full ownership over your area. Lack of bureaucracy or pushback means people welcome new ideas and new ways of thinking.
--MBOs (bonus goals) that keep people accountable and focused on the business
--Very little politics. Whether you've been here a week or 10 years, people treat you the same and value your input.
--Very high bonus structure
--Discounts at Mid-America Club and Athletic Center connected to Aon Center
--You will be pushed to grow and deliver, but it will refine you into your absolute A-game where you are very proud of the work you are doing and the results you are achieving
cons:
--Long hours, demanding work schedule. While not quite like consultant life, this is not a 9-5.
--The design of the every job is to give more to one person than they can normally handle, in the goal of forcing them to prioritize only the most important things. Therefore, things like 1-on-1's, training, team meetings, meet-and-greets...these kinds of things almost never happen, and if they do they're for 30 minutes and feel like an inconvenience. Everyone is so busy that they rarely have time to stop and say hi.
--Some of the MBO's are not even close to achievable. I understand a stretch goal, but having a team reduce cost 10x what they did in a previous year just makes it seem so impossible it's not even worth trying for.
Advice to Management
Make the MBO's a stretch goal, but not so unreasonable that people give up when they receive their MBO target. I've seen too many people completely disheartened and quit simply because the expectations are not in line with reality.
Helpful (2)
Kraft Heinz Company Response
December 19, 2018 – Senior Manager Employer Brand
Oh, the cons you listed and your advice to management is honest and thoughtful, so thank you. I will pass this feedback along. You are right about not having enough time to get to know your coworkers. We are looking at ways to allow for greater connection among employees. - Elizabet
advice_to_mgmt: Make the MBO's a stretch goal, but not so unreasonable that people give up when they receive their MBO target. I've seen too many people completely disheartened and quit simply because the expectations are not in line with reality.

pros:
-Entrepreneurial environment
-Risk-taking encouraged
-Strong Teamwork and Talent
-Diversity of experiences for growth and development
-Flat organization culture
-Individuals can have an impact

I have been with multiple versions of "Kraft" over the past 10+ years. In that time, I have seen a number of models and leaders come through, and the truth is - there are pros and cons to every approach. Basically what you have seen in the most recent iteration of the Kraft journey is a full scale commitment to stripping away the glut of resources that existed (some of which were excess, some were not) to 1. Disrupt the way the company operates and better align to the fast-changing consumer, 2. Challenge our teams to think differently and question the norms of operating, and 3. Force a bottoms-up approach to renovating current businesses and building new businesses for the long term. 

If you ask me, that type of disruption was needed. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the stability, security, and structure of "old" Kraft models. The problem is and was that it was just too darn difficult to get things done and Kraft was no longer able to effectively keep up with consumer demands. "Change is the only constant" has long been a quote used at Kraft. This is the first time we have seen full scale commitment to answering that challenge.
cons:
-Evolving structure
-Change is the constant
-Aggressive goals

KHC does operate like a new company trying to find itself. Employees need to proactively participate in the build and not expect the company to just lay out the steps/path for them. If looking for a highly structured environment, it may not be the right fit. If looking for real ownership, big challenges, and never being bored, KHC fits that build.

It is hard work. Hard work is also the most rewarding work.
Advice to Management
Continue to encourage the pursuit of big ideas and flat organizational culture, empower employees to have the impact they can have while supporting their execution, and celebrate the risk-taking.

In the near term, we do need a level of realism about what it is we can achieve while we build for the future. As I have heard management say many times, we are in this for the long game, so we cannot lose sight of that and drive our people too hard trying to achieve the smaller near term goals.
Helpful (2)
Kraft Heinz Company Response
November 13, 2018 – Senior Manager Employer Brand
Such thoughtful feedback. Thank you. All of the things you mentioned are what sets us apart from other companies. We are flat, fast, and at times, really fabulous. We are also highly aware of our opportunities for improvement. And every day we are diligently working to turn our cons into pros
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue to encourage the pursuit of big ideas and flat organizational culture, empower employees to have the impact they can have while supporting their execution, and celebrate the risk-taking.

In the near term, we do need a level of realism about what it is we can achieve while we build for the future. As I have heard management say many times, we are in this for the long game, so we cannot lose sight of that and drive our people too hard trying to achieve the smaller near term goals.

pros:
I am a legacy Kraft employee and I was terrified when we merged with Heinz - mostly due to the reviews I read on Glassdoor and other sources calling it beyond cut-throat. 

The past 3 years have been my most enjoyable in 25+ years with the company. There is less career pigeonholing and more belief in empowerment than I think exists in most corp cultures. 

When new opportunities arose at the time of the merge (and since), senior management believed in me more than I believed in myself. That has helped to reshape my career. I love Kraft Heinz.
cons:
It is a little youth-centric but it's not intolerable or discriminatory.

review_title: Challenging projects managing iconic brands. Work life balance is tough
pros:
-managing iconic brands and projects! 
-surrounded by brilliant passionate colleagues, no dead weight 
-lean management provides visibility and ability to influence business decisions at the top of the house. Even for junior employees. 
-great location with truly breathtaking views
-fantastic pay when bonus is achieved, average solid pay when not achieved
cons:
Daily deadlines make working 10-12 hour days the norm. This makes it a challenging environment for mothers/parents in particular, who are often forced to choose between seeing their children, and the crushing demands of the job. When we say ‘this culture isn’t for everyone,’ for some it might be the difference between working an 8 hour day or a 12 hour day. You’re right, if you don’t want to work hard, get out, we’re not for you. For others, it means having to choose between work and baby on a daily basis. And being a parent doesn’t end with maternity leave. It’s doable for many parents though with flexibility. If we want to increase retention of parents, I would love to see job share or other flex opportunities. Opportunity to be on a different track for a given period of your career, without feeling you have to quit to get the work/life balance you need. Even small gestures would be appreciated, like religiously sticking to core meeting hours of 9-5. Working parents can hop back online in evening to work, that’s how they make it work, but they want to get home to eat dinner with their family, maybe catch their child’s t-ball game. We can do better here in terms of flexibility and support of families without sacrificing productivity. Leaders set the tone. I’m excited to better understand Lisa’s focus in the coming months. We are counting on her, and are optimistic.
Helpful (2

review_title: Don't be scared about bad reviews, the team can be very good
pros:
1. I was scared before joining KHC reading all the bad reviews. It turned out that a lot of those negative reviews come from inability to adapt to the new world after the merger. If you're considering joining KHC, don't be intimidated about the negative reviews. Trust the energy you feel from the persons you meet. Again, each team is different. 
2. Work life balance is good. I never had insane hours or insane expectations.
3. ZBB is not as bad you might think. It's just watch and responsible about your spending. I won't say the company is cheap at all. It's quite fair.
4. Pay and compensation is good. Some people complains that you might not get your bonus if the company didn't hit target. It's true. But KHC's base pay alone is mid to above market price. You get fair base pay and have huge upside if you perform well. What's there to it to complain about?
5. This one is Your Miles May Vary. But my team is really good and caring and love to help each other out. My boss truely care about me and my growth and offer opportunities for me and my team to grow.
6. There is plenty of promotion opportunities or opportunities to grow into a different role
7. Great AON location and gorgeous view
8. Every week there is activities such as snack testing panel, chef demonstrations etc. quite fun
cons:
1. KHC has no rehire policy. Once you're out of the door, you're out for good. This can hurt in long run.
2. There is no annual merit pay increase. If you don't get promoted, you compensation can stay the same for many years. Maybe that's why there are so many lateral moves?
3. Too many laterals moves that the owner of things constantly changes. This cause disruptions in day to day work.
Helpful (8

pros: Kraft Heinz incentivizes based on performance, has great benefits and wonderful people. If you want to work hard and deliver, you will be rewarded. I also think the company generally has good values. Most of the people are wonderful and have a lot of knowledge and experience.

review_title: Good Opportunity for New Graduates but Better Practices Needed in New Project Approval and Sustainability
pros:
- Trainee program allows the opportunity to take on big projects early
- Opportunities to join groups outside of current role to get involved further in the company
- Well-known brand and reputation
- Local/plant management are responsive and helpful for issues that occur
cons:
- Merger and the following organizational layoffs 
- Lack of a merit-bonus for last year made operators feel that if they exceed expectations and do not receive merit pay, then there is little motivation to do well
- Lack of transparency and feedback from corporate made it seem like concerns or questions were ignored
- Needs more sustainable practices in areas where large volumes of food is sent out to landfill
Advice to Management
Instead of a goals based system for managers only, create a generalized goal system for operators and floor workers. Implement methods to track processes for their yields per shift to give operators more ownership and targets to achieve.

Use a more yield/quality driven system (i.e. increase the impact that scrap/product ratio has only OEE calculation) to stress the need to make good product instead of trying to maintain uptime for product that meets minimal standards. Create a project approval system within ZBB structure so that a variety of managers can bring projects forward and provide cost-benefit data which will help streamline process improvements.
Helpful (1)
Kraft Heinz Company Response
October 1, 2018 – Senior Manager Employer Brand
Thank you for your feedback. I share all of the Glassdoor feedback with our leadership team. You have provided an important perspective that will help us continue to improve. - Elizabet
advice_to_mgmt:
Instead of a goals based system for managers only, create a generalized goal system for operators and floor workers. Implement methods to track processes for their yields per shift to give operators more ownership and targets to achieve.

Use a more yield/quality driven system (i.e. increase the impact that scrap/product ratio has only OEE calculation) to stress the need to make good product instead of trying to maintain uptime for product that meets minimal standards. Create a project approval system within ZBB structure so that a variety of managers can bring projects forward and provide cost-benefit data which will help streamline process improvements.

review_title: Fast Paced But Rewarding With Hard Work
pros: With hard work you can move up in the company quickly and they do not limit you to one area. I have been lucky enough to work in two different departments in my 16 months here. My co-workers are very sharp, motivated, and in general younger than many similar companies. Many places will say they will not hold you back from promotions based on age but Kraft Heinz is one of the few who actually live by this. Finally, they have a scholarship program for your masters which I was selected for and it pays much better than other companies who only give you the tax limit.
cons:
This place demands high talent and isn't for everyone, as a result turnover can be high. Plants were closed which I suspect lead to many of the lower scores but having worked in automotive in 2007 and for a M&A based chemical company, these activities are not limited to Kraft Heinz.

The benefits such as medical aren't great, they are OK but our 401(K) match is good.
Advice to Management
Focus on employee turnover, not getting bonuses hurt this past year. Focus on new products, Springboard is an awesome start!

review_title: Overall Positive Experience from a Young Professional
pros: The essence of Kraft Heinz is meritocracy. This can be both good and bad, but for those people who work hard and seek to excel, the rewards are better than what most companies in this industry offer. Starting salaries are extremely competitive, and bonus targets for most individuals are higher than any other company I've seen. The key is that KHC tries to tie pay to performance as much as possible. From a positive standpoint, this provides great incentive for employees to work on their goals (called MBO's.) I work in Chicago and the office there is great- tremendous views from the 76th floor of the Aon center. The people I've worked with are smart, capable and usually have your best interest in mind. I've been out of college for 3 years and have had good experiences in my short-tenure here.
cons:
Kraft Heinz gets a bad rap for being cut-throat and ill-hearted, and although I think this is over-stated somewhat and that the overarching goals of their processes come from a good place, this can at times feel true. There's a much greater focus on results rather than the work involved to get those results (again, meritocracy is king) and many individuals I've worked with have quit due to intense work hours and sky-high expectations put on them. I've been lucky in that my team has not exhibited these traits, but I can say that others have not been as fortunate.
Advice to Management
Many folks are turned off from Kraft Heinz because of the perception that they're so difficult to work for, and that has cost us innumerable qualified applicants over the past few years. We need to work on this perception, and ultimately re-shape the culture while still focusing on reasonable cost-cutting measures and other processes that will help us in the long-run.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Many folks are turned off from Kraft Heinz because of the perception that they're so difficult to work for, and that has cost us innumerable qualified applicants over the past few years. We need to work on this perception, and ultimately re-shape the culture while still focusing on reasonable cost-cutting measures and other processes that will help us in the long-run.

review_title: KHC is for young employees looking to grow their career
pros: Since KHC is a lean company, roles are loaded with responsibility and opportunity. If you're able to perform at a high rate, there is an expedited trajectory on your career here. The overall benefits are stronger than average here, with above average pay and time off. They have fully embraced the open office environment, which has it's pros and cons, but helps facilitate communication and team interaction. Young and ambitious talent will certainly thrive here.
cons:
KHC's culture is right out of the 3G handbook, where zero based budgeting and KPI's are the main point of emphasis. Simple things like lack of office supplies, printing allowances, and an artificial focus on 5S desk practices can be frustrating at times. They do commit to giving all employees stretch goals for the year, which are contradictory to other teams and create more internal rift than is necessary or normal. Also, there is an upper management focus on top line growth, but a lack of emphasis on giving the relevant teams the resources to achieve it.
Advice to Management
I would encourage management to fully commit to understanding the cons of working at Kraft Heinz, and open up the limited feedback channels that are currently in place. Additionally, an added emphasis on top down development would make a big impact in this current culture.
Helpful (5
advice_to_mgmt: I would encourage management to fully commit to understanding the cons of working at Kraft Heinz, and open up the limited feedback channels that are currently in place. Additionally, an added emphasis on top down development would make a big impact in this current culture.

review_title: Made good friends and learned a lot but went through hell to do it
pros:
You are literally doing the job of 10+ people (in supply chain and logistics especially) so you will gain a lot of experience in a short amount of time 
If you like going away happy hours there will be a lot. One week I had 3 in a row all with people I worked closely with 
Nice view of Chicago
cons:
Any positive review you see on here is most likely because HR is telling people to write them. Go back at least 3 months to get true reviews of how horrible it is. 
After I left I was actually concerned I would bring horrible employee skills to my new job by being a young employee working at Kraft and learning all the wrong ways to act and treat people 
The only thing managers and others care about is $$$ - the experience honestly reminded me of my business ethics courses. Remember studying companies where you had to ask how does this happen? It is due to a highly stressful culture that only cares about 1 thing. Managers lie to their managers and upper management doesn’t have a realistic grasp of how bad things are operationally. 
Ultimately 3G is a holding company that is there to make a quick profit and leave. The short-term is the only thing they care about. 
I ultimately left because I was tired of fighting. Everything you do is to fight for your cause. There is no collaboration because everyone only cares about their own metrics.
Advice to Management
You have people leaving daily. You’re driven by cost and I know you’re seeing the money such high turnover is costing. Invest in more than just making Glassdoor reviews look better. Invest in a long-term strategy.

advice_to_mgmt: You have people leaving daily. You’re driven by cost and I know you’re seeing the money such high turnover is costing. Invest in more than just making Glassdoor reviews look better. Invest in a long-term strategy.

I can truly say that if you take ownership of your work and deliver results, you will get rewarded.

pros:
Culture of Ownership, Meritocracy, Execution and Development.
I Love it! At KHC you will find a true experience of what an ownership culture is like. It’s not for everyone, and that’s what makes it so unique and special. It’s probably the biggest competitive advantage that KHC is building for its long term success. It’s a culture of owners that won’t settle for average or mediocre results. It’s a mindset of continuous improvement and delivery of results. It’s an environment that rewards people for their performance, so individuals can grow at their own pace - Meritocracy!
cons:
Competitive work environment, long and intense hours (not necessarily an issue, but might be for some).
There are clear trade-offs, choices to be made and a very competitive work environment. KHC is very transparent and doesn’t shy away from that. These trade-offs and choices will be different from person to person, so make sure to understand what that means to you. One thing I guarantee, if you identify yourself with the values of Ownership and Meritocracy, there is no better place to be!
Advice to Management
Don’t compromise on Kraft Heinz Culture

pros: Kraft Heinz generally offers pretty competitive salaries relative to industry averages. Also, if you're motivated to move up or become an executive, then Kraft does promote within on merit.
cons:
Kraft Heinz cares very little about their employees. Let's start with the fact that on my first day, I had to scrounge around for pens and notepads for a meeting because they "only ordered office supplies twice a year and were looking to reduce costs".

They also implemented a clean desk policy where only two personal items are allowed, and desks shouldn't have much paper and clutter because "clean desks increase employee productivity". The CEO Bernardo Hees even proceeded to walk around the Chicago office leaving post-it notes on desks that weren't in compliance. Does this sound like a company / CEO that you want to work for?

Requests for help and/or supplies are almost always met with replies along the lines of "make do with what you have" and "employees should go above and beyond for the company because you should act like it's your own company". Management does little to help and often reneges on promises.
