review_title: A Real Review from a Current Employee
pros:
There are many pros to working for Kraft Heinz but I will only list the most important ones. 

1. Upward Mobility. Kraft Heinz is all about meritocracy. It's riddled all over the company website and Head Quarters Office. They notice and reward hard work often, instead of promoting someone just for being in a position for a certain amount of time. I am guessing a lot of reviews written bashing management were upset about being passed up, but if you are not willing to work hard then this company is not right for you. 

2. Compensation and Benefits. Kraft Heinz gave me my first opportunity out of college for employment. I am compensated more than fairly, it consists of a base salary then quarterly bonuses in which you have to earn. The In Store Sales position comes with a company car and they pay for gas as well. They also have an incredible 401k plan and insurance plan as well, and everything is covered with you when you are on-boarded. 

3. Management. This may not be the case for everyone in my position, but my manager genuinely cares about me and my future with the company. He pushes me every day to be better and constantly teaches me new things about the industry and my position as he was a former ISP. We have quarterly appraisals in which we talk about my performance as well as where I see myself in the near future which I think is very important. 

Lastly, I would like to clarify that these are my honest opinions. I know many companies give a bonus or incentive for leaving reviews on this website in a positive light. This is not the case, I genuinely enjoy and am proud to work for Kraft Heinz.
cons:
My only con would be that communication from the top down could be a little more clear. Things get skewed from time to time and information isn't as readily available as I would like it to be, but I also understand that's how this industry works.
Advice to Management
The sales team can feel excluded from the rest of the company from time to time due to working in our set territories and not in an office setting. Getting to know who we are working with at a higher level and their thought processes would be good for the company as a whole.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
The sales team can feel excluded from the rest of the company from time to time due to working in our set territories and not in an office setting. Getting to know who we are working with at a higher level and their thought processes would be good for the company as a whole.

pros: It certainly feels refreshing for a veteran of the Food industry to see how new management with fresh ideas and relentless focus on achieving a vision can drive significant profitable growth through bold decisions, rituals and routines and a firm belief that anyone that beats their objectives and is willing to go the extra mile can do almost anything and make it big in a $30 B iconic company. Watching myriads of young and not-so-young professionals eager to come to take opportunities to head big responsibilities and leave a positive mark is a breath of fresh air in an industry that has been challenged for years by slow growth and changing consumer preferences. Simplicity and discipline inspires those of us that have been a while around, and I can see other "long tenures" enjoying the ride as they embrace the culture. No doubt it is built for those that like to work hard and get rewarded accordingly. I am proof of what meritocracy and ownership mean: have been promoted twice in close to 3 yrs after the merger, doing very exciting and different stuff, adding a collection of new and rewarding experiences that have me at high adrenaline every day I come to office.
cons:
Not for everyone. You have to be comfortable with empowering your people. Disciplined to achieve goals. Methodical to get things done. Coach once and again to both those those that are winning and those not making it, so that everyone has a true chance. You must be everyday fully invested, all hands on deck.
Advice to Management
Don't stop visiting the front line. Bad publicity from those that don't share the vision is not worth distracting from achieving it. Let's go for the next big M&A.

pros:
A large food company with worldwide brands, Kraft Heinz looks to remain a large factor in US and global food markets. With such strong brands, Kraft Heinz is positioned to be a reliable employer for the foreseeable future.

My personal experience as a Continuous Improvement Engineer has been positive at the Champaign IL facility. My work actively helps improve the factories biggest issues, and there is positive engagement with floor employees. I take their biggest issues and help them come up with realistic, effective solutions. Helping making their lives easier is very rewarding, and many positive relationships are made between management and floor employees
cons:
Working in a factory environment can be challenging at times as a liaison between floor employees and management. I am expected to work factory hours, including extra time before and after shift changes, and the occasional project will have me work on off shifts, which can disrupt work/life balance. Having to split the line between management and floor employees gives you great insight into what each side has for expectations, but always causes some tension, since both sides are not always right.

The ideas of meritocracy can be challenging at times, and can definitely be seen in the workplace, which can be frustrating when there is nothing you can do. I have encountered the pressure meritocracy applies to its workers, but I understand its benefits once results are delivered. I feel that this is healthy pressure that keeps people striving to improve, though it can be exhausting at times.
Advice to Management
More active engagement between higher seated management with floor employees. In my CI role, I am constantly working with both management and floor employees, and I understand both of their work environments. I feel there are many management employees that look at workers as numbers in a spreadsheet instead of actual people, and that disconnect makes employees feel that they are not being heard. A more active engagement and communication between both groups could work wonders on factory conditions and employee moral.

More honesty with the conditions the facility and employees face. Instead of only looking for and showing off what is going perfectly, telling the honest truth should be prioritized. I feel too often issues are masked to prevent criticism of work, instead of positive communication and discussion. Communication is one of the most important tools management can use to work with their employees, and when we lie about current situations and issues, we only hurt ourselves in the long run. Active communication and addressing current conditions and issues would work wonders on improving factory conditions
Helpful (1

pros: Family oriented company, great mix of junior to senior employees across the company. Meaningful investment into office culture and employee activities, as well as investment in charitable causes that employees bring forward. Lots of opportunity for advancement into any area of the company; you are not silo'd into one department. Kraft Heinz is not afraid to promote high achievers into bigger roles, so if you are a strong performer, you will advance. Every position has KPIs for meeting business objectives, so you will know your performance level and how you are impacting your team. Other Pros: Strong investment into training platform, with both internal and external resources. High compensation at all levels, family friendly and generous benefits offerings, with many options to choose from. Outstanding 401k match. Lastly, the Kraft Heinz culture is all about being efficient: focus on finding root causes of problems and address them, invest dollars for maximum impact, don't waste energy on tasks that don't add value, find a better way to get the job done. You are truly given the opportunity to own your job and deliver results, and your team is counting on you to do so.
cons:
Like any large company, there are internal communications issues between divisions that need addressing. (There are ongoing efforts from management to address these). Sometimes, longer hours are required depending on assignments or tasks that are coming due. Some inexperience in roles can cause internal frustration, so communication and teamwork are key as employees work together to tackle larger objectives. Kraft Heinz may not be the right fit for those looking for a job where they can float by and punch a clock, but if you driven, confident in your abilities, and appreciate working with a team to achieve a shared vision, it's a great fit.
Advice to Management
Continue to listen to employees to drive innovation and strong focus on the consumer. Continue to invest in employees through training platforms and rewards programs. Continue to push collaboration between divisions from the top down.

review_title: Company culture is sinking the ship.
pros:
Kraft Heinz is a good place to cut your teeth if you're young. You can get some experience and if you're really ambitious you may be able to advance even without an advanced degree.

PTO is all lumped in, no sick days, just 18 PTO days and 12 or so company holidays.

Work Life balance is worsening, but isn't too bad at this location yet.
cons:
Morale is very low, turnover is very high. Advancement appears to be more about luck than anything. There are no cost of living raises, merit raises are few and far between and often end up not being about merit but trying to stop people from leaving the company. While the bonus target is generous, you may meet or exceed your goals and get nothing. Promotion in place is almost non-existent; you have to make several lateral moves before you can advance.

Training is non-existent and company does not appear to value advanced degrees. There are BS, MS, and PhDs in the same salary bands with the same job titles. Everything is learned on the fly, most of the experts have left. Learning internal systems on the fly are one thing, but in R&D expertise should be better valued.

Leadership does not appear to be taking concerns over company culture seriously or are very slow to act. Despite 2017 employee engagement survey, no plan has been rolled out. After bonuses weren't paid out, despite company netting $7 billion due to tax reform, at this location alone ~5-10 employees have quit per month.

Company has open office space and a clean desk policy limiting employees to 2 personal items. No office supplies are to be on your desk, but some desks don't even have drawers underneath them. It's almost a clear signal that you shouldn't make yourself at home; you won't be here long.

Company is extremely cost conscious which often presents lots of hurdles in the way of getting things done. Accounts Payable often struggles to pay clients on time which has strained relationships with vendors already frustrated by length terms of payment. This has caused vendors to put holds on our account and makes work very difficult for those in the trenches.

Company appears to be struggling to grow as seems to be the trend with 3G backed companies thus fueling constant speculation of a merger or acquisition and subsequent layoffs. Leadership appears to dismiss these concerns, but their responses are inadequately soothing.
Advice to Management
You cut to the bone; this is a disaster waiting to happen. Make drastic changes now before it's too late.
Helpful (23
advice_to_mgmt: You cut to the bone; this is a disaster waiting to happen. Make drastic changes now before it's too late.

Advice to Management
If one of management's goals for 2018 is "to do a better job on Employee Turnover" they should consider not cheating their employees out of yearly bonuses. It is extremely difficult to get the most out of a team when they realize that their 50-60 hour work weeks and 100% personal goal achievements, is all for nothing when no bonuses are paid out. It is also unfair to recruit employees with the lure of high bonus payouts, which is simply not true.

It is widely understood that the company had a tough year but employees who have lived up to their goals should not be cheated out of their well-deserved bonuses. Make MBO targets truly individual/team dependent.

* Know that you will be overworked with little training or support.
* HQ support are working on their career growth (and bonus), not yours.
* Get the experience and people network.
* Know that if you're not promoted within 2-3 years: you are probably not getting promoted here.
* Make career/lifestyles decisions that are best for yourself, not the company.
* Kraft will do what's best for the company, not you.
* The company's best interests may include downsizing you for any reason, especially if you don't produce results or fall out of favor with a Team Lead.

review_title: Best place for young & hungry to start your career, but maybe not worth sticking around
pros:
The 5 stars is for the rotational programs for those fresh in their career, to reflect from a pure career standpoint the benefits of joining KHC. However, the company itself, other job functions, and the long-term outlooks aren't as standout.
 
- Amazing Corporate Management Trainee / Sales Trainee / Ops Trainee programs, where you basically get paid to learn a lot, own millions / billions of dollars of real impact, and fast track your career growth. No where else do you get the same level of responsibility, and real exposure and relationships with senior management and even the C-suite, as a fresh-out-of-college kid. 

- Job flexibility & career growth - adding to the above, there is VERY rapid vertical and horizontal opportunities for you within the company. Due to the company culture (young, lean, meritocratic) and to the rotational component of the Corporate Trainee program, you get exposure to almost every part of the business, and work in two completely different job functions, within the first 6 months alone. Movement between Finance and Marketing especially is quite common. Finally, most trainees see movement every ~3-9 months, and most of the time that movement is a promotion. This velocity of movement is unmatched at any firm of competing size & prestige, and feels more like a startup. However, unlike a startup, you get the resources and good name of a big company to back your risk-taking, learning, growth, and ownership.

- Open access to amazing people - each individual is driven and ambitious - we've all bought into this culture of quantified meritocracy. But collectively, the people at KHC are eager to help each other out, especially thanks to the open office culture (no cubicles! no specified hours! free reign & flexibility with where & how you spend your office time) and the constant movement of people to new functions and teams. Somehow, KHC manages to be the best of both worlds - provides a very collaborative and supportive community of peers, while also rewarding extreme individual ambition. 

- ZBB - exposure to ZBB looks great on your business resume, and it is an important efficiency mindset to apply to any business and to your life.

- Ownership and meritocracy. Your career growth here is (mostly) up to you*
cons:
- Job flexibility also means job insecurity -- those who get the most out of KHC and move up the fastest are willing and eager to take every opportunity, but that often means common job & team changes, which isn't for everyone. Layoffs and pressure to perform can also be stressful. 

- Poor work-life balance for finance functions

- ZBB takes a toll on company morale - it's great that we save money from going to waste and see it pay out as higher bonuses, but paying for plastic forks during lunch and not having many company bonding events really sucks

- Minority representation in the company as a whole, but especially as you move up, is subpar, much like at many peer companies. 

- Career growth is best for Brazilians, then males, then Caucasians, with everyone else still able to grow quickly but clearly limited by their minority status... 

- The company is more focused on cost-cutting (which is a temporary way to improve returns) than innovation (which is the long-term vision needed to improve our viability in the market vs. competitors). Lack of real innovation is pretty standard at such large companies, though.

- The above mentioned short-term focus manifests because of the very young teams and high turnover -- there's no incentive for the long term, when your bonuses and performance are measured by monthly & quarterly & 1-year goals, and when you leave your current project / team / company in mere months / very few years. 

- The company seems pretty hit or miss. Those who are young, flexible, hungry, and willing to tough it out really come across amazing opportunities and unparalleled career growth vs. anywhere else you can kick start your career. But that's more due to the youth, inexperience, and lack of structure in the company, than it is due to actual development efforts or actual company growth. I would highly recommend any young person to come to KHC, but would not recommend to anyone to stay too long, for two reasons. One, the entire industry and this company too will probably struggle to keep up with changing food trends. Two, because of the stress on meritocracy, high turnover and young managers makes development and real leadership lacking.
Advice to Management
- Give real answers to difficult questions, i.e. "lack of females in upper management" --> HR spits back the typical PR phrase "we are being thoughtful and taking action to combat this" without quantifying how.

- More company events to create sense of community & joint culture, in addition to the purely individualistic "meritocracy / ownership" culture

- Work more cross-functionally to align incentives, and work to reduce communication frictions across the company

- Be more upfront, honest, transparent, and approachable with UR communications with university hires

- Train managers to be proper managers and team leads. Likewise, make sure the high velocity movement of people throughout the company does not wear down on team cohesion and efficiency.

review_title: Started with high hopes, but was soon disappointed
pros:
-There are some truly amazing people at Kraft Heinz who work hard and are friendly. Sadly they usually don’t seem to stick around since they don’t want to stay in such an unhappy, negative workplace. Most people are stressed and just trying to make it one year before leaving. You can browse LinkedIn and see for yourself how lots of people who work at Kraft only last a little over a year.

-Kraft has great name recognition and used to treat its employees well (just look at the glowing Kraft reviews on Glassdoor from before the Kraft Heinz merger!) so when I told people I worked at Kraft they were impressed, unless they knew how 3G companies run and then they would always ask me how I was handling the stress.

-When I decided to leave Kraft, their growing reputation as a stressful, unhappy place to work meant it was easy to explain why I was looking for a new job.
cons:
When Kraft Heinz offered me a job they promised big, exciting, and difficult projects, motivated team members, and professional growth. Within weeks I realized everything they promised either had a dark underbelly or was a flat out lie.

-It feels like the biggest reason they have lots of opportunities for growth is that every few months they lay off a big group of people. This creates a tense environment because you’ll routinely see people pushed out. Even high performers can be laid off if they had the bad luck of being on a team Kraft no longer needs, unless they’re offered a transfer onto a team they have no interest in joining, maybe even in a totally different field.

-The Kraft Heinz recruiter convinced me to take a lower salary than I planned on accepting because she bragged how the bonus structure is amazing since we’re all owners here! It wasn’t until I started that I heard you only get the full bonus if you hit all your targets and also the company does well enough to approve paying out 100% of employees’ earned bonuses. I also heard later that recruiters’ bonuses depend in large part on filling roles really quickly, but not how long you actually stay at Kraft. This means it is really tempting for them to promise anything to get you accept, even if it’s an exaggeration and there’s a chance you’ll want to leave Kraft upon learning the truth.

-No matter why you leave Kraft, you can almost never be rehired again. They don’t care if you’re quitting because of a family move, a personal tragedy, or an amazing new job opening up elsewhere. They believe loyalty to Kraft is the most important thing so you should never have to leave. I see this as a sign of how they view employees’ personal lives.

-Kraft asks a lot from its employees and promises meritocracy in return. It is a lot like a big 10 school, really rah-rah, and it feels like a lot of employees come from work hard, party hard schools. But since the best opportunities seem to go to Brazilians first, then men and there are constant layoffs, people get discouraged fast.
Advice to Management
Any time somebody points out a problem at the company that’s linked to the culture, like the crazy work hours, stress that comes from constant layoffs, or how people routinely cry in the bathroom, it feels like HR just shrugs and says the problem is that the complainer isn’t burning with ambition. Kraft refuses to truly evaluate the long term sustainability of the way they work and treat employees. It feels like they are always doing employee satisfaction surveys because they know there’s a serious culture problem, but they refuse to acknowledge you just can’t ask employees to sacrifice so much health, time, and energy without creating a stressful and negative workplace.

Because my team was so difficult, the work/life balance was poor, and the overall work environment was unhappy I ended up finding a new job. When I told people at Kraft I was leaving I was shocked how many people said they were jealous I was going because they were also unhappy. Even people I thought loved Kraft said they wished they were also leaving. It reassured me that the problems I was having at Kraft weren’t just about me, but it’s also upsetting because it means there are huge problems that nobody feels comfortable talking about openly and these problems are just getting bigger and bigger. Those problems also mean Kraft is gaining a more public reputation as a rough place to work, meaning talented people are going to start avoiding Kraft. Kraft wants risk-takers who are looking for a challenge, but it feels we are rapidly approaching the point where smart, driven risk takers will see Kraft just offers too much instability to be worth it.

review_title: Be very hesitant considering positions here. Know what you are getting into. Read all reviews.
pros:
Decent starting salary. 
Some very knowledgable teammates.
PTO days.
cons:
Where to begin.. 

Yesterday, January 3rd, the company sent an email out to all employees confirming that a majority will not receive a bonus for 2017. In my case, and a lot of people I've talked to since that email, I reached almost 100% of my MBO's (measuring stick that KraftHeinz uses for measuring your goals/targets which determines your bonus) and am receiving nothing. Yet, certain functions are receiving their bonus for having a "remarkable year." KraftHeinz constantly pushes Meritocracy to it's employees, "the direct link between delivering results and earning rewards." Well, the removal of bonuses proves that to be one huge lie.

Meeting MBO goals usually requires extremely long hours, which is common throughout the company. Management routinely asks for this, often creating tensions and stress about meeting deadlines which many times prove to be unimportant. The amount of 11+ hour days put in throughout 2017 to make sure my goals were met are countless. My team had no qualms putting the extra work in, but giving all of these hours meeting our team's goals and getting nothing in return due to some higher level screw up is unacceptable.

In that same email sent to employees yesterday, just after the quick 15 word sentence stating no bonuses will be given to most employees and after the 5 lessons to learn from in 2017 (#5 was: "Do a better job on Employee Turnover....reducing turnover worldwide"), KraftHeinz lists exactly forty three bullet points of positive take aways from 2017. Forty three. I'm sure that will help impacted employees feel better.

Good luck improving turnover this year. Motivation is at an all time low.
Advice to Management
Nothing worth mentioning that management hasn't heard already.
Helpful (38
advice_to_mgmt: Nothing worth mentioning that management hasn't heard already.

review_title: Constant grind with very poor work/life balance
cons:
ant grind with very poor work/life balance"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee - Marketing in Chicago, IL
Doesn't Recommend
Neutral Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I worked at Kraft Heinz Company full-time
Pros
Iconic brands.
Pay is good, particularly the annual bonus - if you are able to hit the target.
Downtown Chicago location.
Cons
After the Kraft Heinz merger, the 3G management style made this a very different place to work than the one I originally joined. 
-There is a monthly grind that just never stops. You are expected to get everything done incredibly fast, no matter how short of notice you are given and regardless what you may have going on in your personal life. 
-Costs are being continually and aggressively stripped out of iconic food brands, regardless of how much it degrades the quality of these products. 
-It is a male dominated culture, particularly the higher you get in the company. If you are a Brazilian male, you have just punched your golden ticket to the top. If you are a female, they will happily take you as a work horse in a junior role for a few years - but you will hit a glass ceiling.
-The highly touted "meritocracy" is a joke. The turnover is so high at this company, either from frequent layoffs or from people quitting, that there is a constant stream of open roles. The solution is a combination of either piling more and more work on those who are left, (without any increase in pay,) or pushing really junior, inexperienced people into roles that that are not ready to handle, and calling it "meritocracy." 
-The company spends a lot of time and effort on some really bizarre things. (e.g. No more than 2 personal items on your desk. CEO and senior execs walking around to check how clean your desk area is, and placing red flags on untidy desks like a public shaming of some sort.)
Advice to Management
Focus on building leaders, and reward strong leadership - not just robots who can hit their MBO metrics. Leadership is not something that you will get with people who are fresh out of college, no matter how book smart they are. And diversify your middle and senior management. You need more women and non-Brazilian men in these roles.
Helpful (23
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on building leaders, and reward strong leadership - not just robots who can hit their MBO metrics. Leadership is not something that you will get with people who are fresh out of college, no matter how book smart they are. And diversify your middle and senior management. You need more women and non-Brazilian men in these roles.

iPad - NEW TECHNOLOGY! Until the iPad decides to not work or their apps stop working or faulty information is sent to HQ and then you're made to look like you're not actually doing your job when you are.

AMAZING PTO! Great PTO until you realize the PTO is pro-rated and if you use more than the allotment, you owe them money (if you decide to part ways beforehand).

Work/Life Balance - OR SO THEY SAY. If you have a great boss who understands LIFE then you're fine. HQ expects you to be in your first store at 6:30 and finish 3-4 stores per day. If you don't hit all stores in 1 week, it's marked against you.

Great benefits - Hope you're not married or have kids.
cons:
ant communication between management and lower level employees! Expect to have conference calls every day that take up your mornings, which, in turn, will make you miss time in your stores and then, will push back your entire day, the e-mails from the CRM team that completely take up your inbox, which will give you anxiety about your workday ahead of you, and the reports. WHO DOESN'T LOVE REPORTING? Constant reporting, because, this job is not "sales," it's reporting and merchandising.

Sign on bonuses! Oh.. we're not supposed to talk about those. Most people got them, a lot didn't. I'm glad I didn't.

Phone allowance - $40 per paycheck. Company couldn't get the payment together. After 2 months, finally received the allowance.

Bonuses - Easy to achieve at first. Company realized this, then made the metrics harder and less obtainable, so they don't have to pay their employees.
Cons
Beat out of my bonus that I hustled to get.
Monthly meetings that ruin 1 Thursday a month for you. Have fun sitting in traffic.

Is there a "check all" box?

#WASTEMYTIME2017
Advice to Management
Stop portraying this job as a sales job. It is analytical reporting. HIRE REPORTERS or merchandisers, not "salespeople." HQ can easily obtain this information at the drop of a hat, but they'll hire people, waste their time, and then wonder why we're unsatisfied with our jobs. If I wanted to be a merchandiser, I would've applied to a merchandising role. GET BETTER RECRUITERS, they're a bunch of liars. Stop saying there's advancement and meritocracy when hiring/promotions go to Brazilians and outside applicants. People who are working extremely hard for you, should be promoted. No one wants to waste their time doing your reports that someone in HQ could easily do. Lastly, from Chicago to the Northeast, there is a time difference. FYI when having conference calls at 5:30pm.

review_title: Run the other way. If you don't, you'll be looking for a new job soon once you see how this company operates.
pros: Great opportunities to advance within the company if you like working 60-70 hours a week for the privilege of being promoted to the captain of a sinking ship!
cons:
Since 3G took over Kraft Foods (Kraft Heinz merger) things have gotten progressively worse. The new company claims to be based on meritocracy---but high performers are only rewarded with more work, sometimes as much as was previously handled by 3-4 people. You can't do the amount of workload being assigned without working 60-70 hour weeks. Don't ask to work from home---they are in the process of doing away with that---and being met with strong resistance from employees. Company is desperate to attract new talent because they have cut too deep and angered existing employees to the point that people are quitting left and right. An absolute mistake for anyone to consider working here. If you see any positive reviews, they are either planted by HR or from people that work offsite and buffered from the nonsense (not at Chicago or Pittsburgh HQ). Company imports supply chain workers on specialized visas from Europe and Brazil who have no identifiable special skills other than the ability break any and all established standards of workplace decorum. One even started commenting on the election on the day after Trump won loudly to other employees---hello?! Discussion of politics is not appropriate in the workplace. Also, to give another idea of the way they operate----the CEO and another senior executive took time out of their busy schedules to walk all 5 floors occupied by Kraft Heinz at the AON Center placing red flags on any desk of employees with more than two personal items on their desks.
Advice to Management
The clock is ticking before the whole house of cards implodes----maybe then, they will realize their mistakes, but I wouldn't count on it!
Helpful (22
advice_to_mgmt: The clock is ticking before the whole house of cards implodes----maybe then, they will realize their mistakes, but I wouldn't count on it!

I left Kraft a few months ago and after working at a new position it almost feels like PTSD settling into a normal environment. People never said thank you at Kraft, it was always MORE MORE WHAT'S NEXT. No appreciation or value for employees, and that's shown through constant layoffs. Everyone is on edge and overworked. Everyone who I know that is inside the organization is planning on leaving after their contract is up, because they can't handle the environment anymore.

pros: The company owns many large and recognizable brands that you will likely have the opportunity to manage. Your friends and family will know what your brands.
cons:
The company tends to say one thing but act in a much different way. 

Meritocracy is, as many other reviewers have noted, basically a sham. Those with great (green) MBO's are continually passed over for folks with poor results but are good networkers. While you'd think Meritocracy would mean that face-time and networking are less important at KHC, it's the exact opposite. You must network twice as hard and stay in the office twice as long because the people you are counting on to help you might be gone next week. Also, Brazilians clearly are favored. Constantly "reassigned" during shake-ups, never fired.

KHC is for "Owners only"... well, except if you mean literal owners of the organization. Within a month of the merger, the employee stock purchase plan was cancelled. Hmm... so, not owners?

The huge focus on innovation is not true either. "Big" innovation wins include putting a food service mustard into the Heinz ketchup bottle. Don't expect something breakthrough anytime in the near future. There's simply no investment to make it happen.

Now about all that cost cutting allowing the organization to re-invest in brands... That's not really happening unless you count wasting money on Super Bowl commercials that have no payback. 

The biggest issue, however, is the lack of talent. The days of going to Kraft to earn your stripes is over. Talented marketers have either been let go or left willingly. You're left with a ton of Corporate Management Trainees that have been empowered to think their you know what doesn't stink but really have no idea what they are doing and, in many cases, treat their peers and cross functional teams like garbage. This is a ME culture, not a WE culture. 

If you want a title, if you want the (slim) chance to make a huge bonus, then maybe this is the place for you. I will say these CMT's are absolutely meant for this culture but in a lot of cases are not the cream of the crop in terms of peers. I've never had someone ten years my junior with no idea what they are doing talk as disrespectfully to me as they CMTs did.
Advice to Management
Better find another acquisition soon because the street is not happy with 3Gs continual inability to show any organic top line growth.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: Decent money. Nothing else good about it.
cons:
High turn around, low morale, no supervision, management is lost, no direction. Ever since Heinz took over this place has gone downhill. They cut, cut, cut to the bone, then wonder why there aren't enough people to run the place efficiently. Supervisors know little to nothing about the goings on out on the floor. They are constantly shuffled from shift to shift and are never engaged with their people. Lackadaisical attitude towards everything. "I don't know how to do that, the next shift will get it, etc" No ownership. If an operator makes a mistake or screws up they are disciplined with a swift and heavy hand. If you are anything above a floor operator you have a huge target on your back. You never know if your job will be eliminated from day to the next. One positive I guess is that when they eliminate jobs (which they do alot) the job goes away, not the employee. They just say you are doing this job now. Like it or leave basically. If you are not a machine operator and are close to retirement you might as well pack your bags because your going to be done soon. They cut out all OT but now can't sustain production because of lack of people. Temporary service provides (mostly) good employees but they make a fraction of what a full timer makes doing the same job.

pros: Hourly wage was good for the area.
cons:
Where to start..this used to be a great company and had employees that felt like family. Upon my leaving everyone was at each others throats. Morale was down. Supervisors would not stand up for long term employees. Management only cares about getting their numbers out and NOT the quality of the product. I cannot for the life of me understand how a major food company would NOT want to care about the quality of their products. Union is a joke for hourly employees and they only fight for those they choose to fight for..after paying for Union dues for almost 20 years they did NOTHING for me when I seriously needed them. Daily scheduling is super hard on employees and scheduling and management do not care...you can be scheduled 8 hours but can get forced to work 12 and get threatened to work more or lose your job if you refuse. Seriously think the original owners of Heinz would be horrified to hear of all the negative things going on in a company they loved for so long. It has gotten run to the ground since the takeover from Warren Buffet and now with the merge with Kraft, I honestly do not know how the company in Muscatine is still open, especially after the gravy recall in 2016. My advice to people working there currently...do NOT be surprised when the place shuts down, due to the company's lack of wanting to spend money to fix machines that are older then dirt, poor judgement calls on quality of the product and several other issues I hope to god no one ever seriously gets poisoned or hurt by eating/using their products. I have so many stories I could tell about this company but I just don't have the time or room.
Advice to Management
Hard to give advice to management when they leave just as fast as hourly workers do. Advice to new members of management..treat your production workers with respect..they are the ones putting out the product and making the product. Start caring about the quality of product you are shipping out and do NOT worry about getting those numbers out..pretty soon those numbers are NOT going to matter when you keep sending out bad product...No customers are going to be buying this product if it continues to be bad and have recall issues. I no I will not be buying things made in Muscatine. I know what goes on there and I can just imagine it only got worse after I left. Take a look at ex employees that may try to come back..not everyone that left is a bad person..some got forced to leave through no choice of their own but the companies policies on medical leave and such. And long term employees that did one job 25+ years ago may not be able to do that same job today but are able to do other jobs and should NOT have to go to a doctor every year telling you that.

pros: Pretty good pay and co workers are great
cons:
I don't even know where to begin... just don't work here. The work/life balance is terrible, and you won't be able to move up much unless you are Brazilian. Dont get me wrong, I love my Brazilian co workers and If I were them I would take advantage as well, but they also know about the unfair treatment that they get. During the hiring process, they're going to throw out words like 'meritocracy' and 'ownership'. That is just code for 'lack of managerial support' and 'have way too many responsibilities for one person so you have to take your work home'. Everyone is stretched so thin that people have so many priorities-that nothing is a priority anymore. This company only cares about cutting costs and bottom line growth, but this can only be temporary. They're not worried about their long term growth or their consumers. Everyone who works here knows that it is just slowly dying. You cant just keep cutting costs and expect more people to buy the products. I will say though, there are some people who thrive in this environment-- people who make their entire lives about work and would be okay with staying at the office until 8 or 9 pm.
Advice to Management
Invest more in your employees

advice_to_mgmt: Invest more in your employees

review_title: Good if you like short term benefits
pros: Meritocracy is really true in this company. Regardless of your background if you over-delivery (not just accomplish your goals) you will have a very high potential to get promoted quickly in the fist 2 years of work. You will get a salary increase and a big new responsibility where you will need to again surpass your goals if you want to stay at least in your role.
cons:
As the only way the meritocracy works is by having enough openings every year in the company. That means that for you, or someone else, to leave the company sooner or later so don't think this company as a long carrier focus. If you like stability no matter you are achieving your goals look for something else. If you have always over deliver and you think you like to work 12 hrs a day you will certainly get rewarded and compensated. Generally they let go the individuals who are more expensive and are not able to achieve their goals the first moment you are not able to deliver. There is no second opportunity as you have become a cost center and not a profit center. Every year the targets are higher as the company has already consumed all of the low hanging fruits and unless the investors buys another company the results you have to achieve are almost impossible so means you will have to leave the company very soon.
Helpful (8

review_title: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway & 3G destroying everything
pros: I'm close to home still and have a job .
cons:
This company has went to pot since the merger. It is sad that such a great company can be torn apart like this. Every year since the merge the company takes away more and more from the employees to make it look like they are making money, They froze the employees retirements. Cuts to the 401k so now they only get 100 percent match of the first 2 percent put in a employee can put in another 4 percent only getting 50 cent match on it per dollar so they can only in reality get 4 percent match all together now with the other 2 percent being matched after a year so you also lose out on all the interest that money would have made you through the year. The company does nothing for employees anymore as they are way overworked as when the economy had started to crash the company had done all types of job cuts to stay at float. Now since the merger they are still cutting to make it look like they are making money. As you always heard you can only squeeze a turnip so much till it bleeds. Well the employees unfortunately are giving a lot of blood these days. The company is taking so much away from the employees I doubt the employees will ever get a chance to retire. The employees are having to be on call for overtime 6 days a week without any incentives for being on call a rude awaking for the former Kraft employees that had at one time been like a family oriented company. Well so much for family now. Warren Buffett and the 3G get rich while they run the company and their employees into the ground. I guess History will repeat itself. I just hope they hurry up and sell the company and hopefully someone gets it that cares about their employees again before some consumer gets hurt from all the cuts that has affected the Quality of the product.
Advice to Management
Money ain't everything if your cutting you may want to trim from the top.It is never good to mess with the foundation if the employees are treated good you only get good in return .

pros: Kraft Foods was a great company at one time -- rich with hard working, ethical colleagues that had fun -- up until about 8 years ago. Current intense focus on obtaining younger work force -- great opportunity if you are 24 and do not have a family to go home to.
cons:
After over 25 years of my life dedicated to Kraft and surviving multiple layoffs, company split and eventual hostile take-over by 3G, those of us left had to absorb work load of others and were in constant fear of being part of the next layoff or in fear of not being layed-off. CEO and most of management team from Brazil with their own Brazilian good ole boy network. Work life balance is when you are allowed to go home and logon to do more work, if you are lucky.
Advice to Management
Rather than eliminating jobs and taking over new companies to make money, try to take the company you acquired and nourish and build it up. If you must eliminate positions, find out what the people did before you let them go and ensure that needed work is transitioned. Those left to pick-up the pieces waste a lot of time figuring out what was needed and the easiest way to do it.

review_title: Good place to start out and learn
pros:
This is a great place to start your career. You'll get a lot of responsibility early.
If you can survive the grind and gain favor with upper management to move up quickly, then you'll stand to work thru the rough culture.

Growth upward can be stalled by waiting for a spot to open up, but people leave frequently so openings are typically not an issue.
cons:
Lower pay than industry. They try to make up for it w/ your bonus target, but many targets are made to be difficult (unless set your annual plan well). 

Upper management is incentivized to grow whole portfolio which can be at the expense of smaller brands/businesses. This can make it extremely tough to get resources to grow your business if you're responsible for a smaller brand, which you're personally incentivized against.
Advice to Management
Better manage rotations. Rotating everyone across all functions leaves little institutional knowledge creating unnecessary churn. It also creates very little sense of responsibility for long term impact of your actions.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Better manage rotations. Rotating everyone across all functions leaves little institutional knowledge creating unnecessary churn. It also creates very little sense of responsibility for long term impact of your actions.

review_title: Come and Talk to us they said... Ushering you out they will
pros: Rotational program was pretty good. There are lots to learn, and you will be exposed to all functions within Kraft Heinz.
cons:
The HR doesn't really communicate with you. Most are closed door processes and you will often be surprised to what you will get on the rotations. Many within the program tried to communicate with the HR so that they can receive clearer view about their destinations, but most efforts resulted to be futile.

They make lots of promises, but it is here where I learned not to trust anything that's not written down on the contract. Again and again, they will go back and pretend they never made any promises.

Favoritism plays a big part here. Once you get on the good side, you can do almost anything and not get fired. If you are not on the good side, well... good luck.
Advice to Management
There needs to be more communication between the HR and the trainees/employees as "surveys" are not enough to fully encapsulate what the employees want. There is a reason why there is such a high turnover rate.

review_title: Kraft Heinz: A company that crushes the soul
pros: The only pro is that the Chicago office has a nice view.
cons:

review_title: Kraft used to be a Great company...until Heinz took over.
pros: If you like 12 hour work days, low pay, new job requirements every week, work for people with no ethics and no manners (people have been name called on a regular basis), work in a company where you will only grow professionally if you be friend the right people, then this is the company for you.
cons:
More work and responsibilities without salary revisions or increase. No work life balance. Kraft had great benefits that were eliminated once Heinz took over. Heavy workload. Questionable ethics (you will not believe the things i have seen that go unseen by upper management). NO MERITOCRACY, despite what company says. No structured job positions, you do as you are told period, even if its not in your job description. Highest turnover I have seen in any company.
Advice to Management
If an employee works more than 8 hours every day then they are not being productive and the headcount is not enough. Management should get training on how to actually be managers and not dictators. Earned benefits should not be taken away from employees as this is the equivalent of salary reductions.

pros: Kraft was once a great company with smart people who have the foundational training to know how to do marketing right. They hired the best and brightest and were maniacally focused on financial growth.
cons:
Due to the maniacal focus on finance and the bottom line, Kraft neglected the topline. They forgot that the key today in driving growth in CPG is bringing innovation. They did not understand what the word meant and in a world where "cash is king" (they literally made every employee go to a seminar with that title) there is no room for innovation to drive topline growth, as that pre-determines short term bottom line impact. They learned their lesson and now with 3G, it's only gotten worse.
Advice to Management
Learn the basics of CPG. You NEED people in the company who have this expertise and mindset or you cannot succeed. Before you decide that driving topline growth and taking a long term view is not important, look out 3-5 years and you will see that if you continue on this collision course, there will not even be pieces left to sell off. As you continue to deplete brand equity, your assets will disintegrate. It is a shameful way to memorialize those who built them.

review_title: Not a Good Environment; You Will Never Feel Secure
pros: Downtown Chicago location; Lots of opportunity to interact with executive leadership; Opportunities to lead projects/work without a lot of micromanagement; Fast paced environment; Lots of promotion potential if you are the right kind of employee
cons:
A lot of the reviews you will read about this company come from people talking about how the old Kraft or the old Heinz were great and the new company is terrible. This might sound to some like the reviews are coming from bitter former employees who were let go for not being up to par, or maybe people who don't handle change well, etc. That may be true. But don't assume that all the negative reviews come from substandard employees. 

The company truly does not have a long term vision for how they will continue to operate at current pace. The 3G model is all about cutting costs and experience - replacing high cost, highly experienced employees with young, inexpensive MBA talent. And there is nothing wrong with that at the surface. The problem occurs when that young, inexperienced talent is brought in to lead projects/department, etc. and they don't have anyone to coach, mentor, or train them. There are serious risks that the company takes and exposes itself to, because the decision makers may only have a couple of years in the workforce and don't know what they don't know.

It is becoming less and less common to find people that have been with the company for more than 2 or 3 years, 5+ years (outside of the manufacturing environment) is extremely rare. This company may be a good place for a young MBA grad to get an iconic company name on their resume, maybe even get promoted quickly, and then get out after two years to go find a "real" job. The problem is that that person will quickly find themself failing in any other management role outside of KHC because they have not learned the fundamental things a manager needs to know to succeed in any normal business.

Finally, no mater who you are, you will not be immune to the constant, unexpected layoffs. of course after the acquisition of Kraft, many Kraft employees were let go. Not a huge surprise, but the number of people laid off, and they type of roles eliminated were somewhat concerning. Then, the field restructuring was announced, and hundreds more manufacturing employees will be let go over time as plants consolidate and close. Then, a few months ago, another round of corporate restructuring meant about 200-300 more salaried employees were let go. And this time, it wasn't just the "low hanging fruit" - underperformers or redundant roles. It was the result of senior management saying, "We need to save $XXXXXX in salaries, so each team needs to cut X number of people. Figure it out." So strong performers were let go. Many of the remaining experienced people were let go. people who were critical to major projects were let go. So now what? Already lean teams need to scramble to fill holes, expensive consultants need to be brought in to pick up the work, and the bare minimum level of work will get done. There won't be opportunities to really produce good, quality work. If you are still there, you won't ever feel proud of your work, because your team is so lean, you all have to work yourselves day and night just to produce the bare minimum, because there are no resources available to you. And you will do that day after day because every day you are afraid of losing your job.
Advice to Management
It won't matter. They aren't in this for the long term. Management is predominantly Brazilian, 3G employees who came from another 3G company, and will move on to the next 3G company when they have squeezed all they can out of Kraft Heinz.
Helpful (48
advice_to_mgmt: It won't matter. They aren't in this for the long term. Management is predominantly Brazilian, 3G employees who came from another 3G company, and will move on to the next 3G company when they have squeezed all they can out of Kraft Heinz.

pros: I really like the culture at Kraft Heinz. It's face paced, results driven and you can really make an impact. In many areas there is little corporate bureaucracy so you can make changes and get things done. The company can also be quite to promote from within and give raises based on results. I just got an unexpected 15% increase.
cons:
There has been a lot of upheaval and culture change since the merger. Can be rough to adjust to ZBB (zero based budgeting - income equals outgo) but I think it allows the company to be more efficient and invest money back into the business and employees instead of spending it on non-essential things.
Advice to Management
Better internal communication to employees, coaching managers so they are in line with culture of meritocracy.

pros: Pay is nice is if you can stay long enough to get full rate, especially if you're in a rate 6 position. Some coworkers can be very nice. Benefits were excellent
cons:
Union takes their cut of your check and does almost nothing for you. Morale is VERY LOW. If you're at production level, you're not cared about. I Most maintenance workers are idiots. 2 scheduled shutdowns per year, plus numerous unscheduled shutdowns where you can file for unemployment, but good luck actually getting paid. Corporate office and owners are the epitome of greed. Working on the line is the most mind-numbing, godawful job ever. Only way to somewhat have a personal life is if you're on the AM shift. I could write a book about all the bad things with this company. Would not recommend anyone go for a job here unless you're single and don't do anything outside of working

pros: Great name on your resume.

Horrible management. If you are looking for a job at a company that will care about you-- this is NOT IT. 

They could care less about their people. The only thing that matters to them is profit and loss. The politics are so awful- people are encouraged to stay quiet during certain meetings by upper management. Long hours are expected- people will literally ask you where you are going if you try to leave the office at 5. Some teams are expected to work until midnight regularly. 

They are so focused on cutting costs that in Chicago the employees are forced to pay for plastic utensils at lunch. 

It is not a place for growth and development. It is a place where people are smothered and broken. If you care at all about being happy at work, you will not even consider taking a job here. People literally quit every single week. It is so unstable.

pros: None since the merger. Technically, you will draw a below market average paycheck, and they have not completely eliminated medical benefits, though the new plans are a far cry from the old offerings.
cons:
Too many to list. They no longer offer competitive pay, there is zero work/life balance. Management (3G) since the takeover has been a complete joke. If you are not young, single, male and Brazilian, good luck in advancing your career. The corporate culture was destroyed, there is no real identity anymore. Everything is about cutting cost and fostering an environment of "healthy conflict." They will entice new applicants with large bonus targets that are completely unreachable. Senior management has demonstrated no competence that they can run a business as large and diverse as Kraft.

Pension was eliminated, you are now frowned upon taking PTO. There is no work/life balance (I worked nights & weekends when not in the office - and still it was never enough.) People do things because of MBO's (goals, called Management By Objectives) vs. what is best and right for the organization. There is little/no collaboration. I have witnessed actual instances of bullying and intimidation. It is a crime what that place has become.

I could only recommend this place if you were in a dire situation (near foreclosure or something close to that.) Even then, I cannot fathom anyone staying in a place like this longer than a year. There is a reason this company is rated so poorly, the majority of the legacy Kraft talent (great folks) were laid off or proactively resigned. Listen to the warnings here. For the life of me, I cannot imagine a more poorly run organization or a worse company to go to than this place. Anything, and I mean anything, is better than this toxic environment, If you do decide to roll the dice and accept a position here, be warned, and keep one eye open always. Your colleagues may very well be out to get you.
Advice to Management
None worth noting as they don't care what people think. Instead, my advice to prospective applicants is to stay away until after Kraft and 3G are no longer aligned. As long as the Brazilians are running this company, it will continue to be a breeding ground of mistrust, contempt and agony. I truly believe this is the worst company in the U.S. to work for, and I challenge anyone to find one worse than this place.

review_title: Glad to have dismounted off this dead horse!
pros:
New Kraft Heinz still has strong brands with great household penetration.
Base salary and bonus structure remains attractive among Food & Beverage companies.
Laser like focus on Zero Based Budgeting.
cons:
There is no vision or strategy to grow the brands and organically grow the firm! The only strategy they pursue is ZBB which includes counting office supplies and eliminating 40% of head count to achieve savings and increase EBITDA.
Senior management (C level) are all comprised of freckle faced, intelligent Brazilians but grossly inexperienced in running a global CPG firm with $28B revenue. They have very low emotional quotient and hence cannot be good leaders or motivate and manage people. They are more concerned with running endless transactional minutia and routines (40 routines per week, sometime people have to provide daily updates on 5 tasks)! They have no clue as how to defend market share and as a result will lose more market share, means less revenue and then reduce more head count and the cycle continues...
The workplace is a revolving door. The talent base has been decimated in all functions through massive lay-offs. I would estimate that 30% of corporate positions have been eliminated - some of the top talent survived the first 2 waves but then in Jan 16 85 people resigned and moved on. The new talent they hired fit the 3G mold with 0 CPG experience. As a result the people left behind are perennially looking for jobs! Even the head of ZBB resigned!
The management by objectives (MBO) is nothing special but a smart goal system which is publicly visible. But it allows a quarterly evaluation of your performance vs. goals and hence you can get fed after Q2 for not hitting your goal!
Advice to Management
Berkshire Hathaway - as the largest share holder and board member you need to fire the entire management team and steer the company into becoming a food and beverage firm with energized brands which generate sustainable profits while moving into the health, wellness and organic segments.
Helpful (29
advice_to_mgmt: Berkshire Hathaway - as the largest share holder and board member you need to fire the entire management team and steer the company into becoming a food and beverage firm with energized brands which generate sustainable profits while moving into the health, wellness and organic segments.

pros: The people in non-management roles are extremely talented and genuinely nice people. This is a great place to learn how to do big things with a small team and little to know budget. If you're willing to work hard and put in the time, you will get promoted into bigger and broader roles. You'll either do great things or be part of the cuts and layoffs.
cons:
Do a general search on LinkedIn and you'll find the company's management team and expats are comprised primarily of Brazilian team members from AmBev, ALL, 3G or another Brazilian company. The company should "eat its own dog food" and promote from within and diversify talent outside of just the Brazil population. HR also needs to do a better job of preparing first-time people managers for the bigger roles they're promoted to. I could go on and on, but you can read for yourself. All the reviews post-3G acquisition are absolutely true.
Advice to Management
Diversify your talent. Prepare first-time people managers. The trainee program should feed into entry-level roles, not specialized professional level positions. Teach your Presidents and EVPs to coach and lead, not cuss and yell at their teams in hopes of driving work results.

pros: Only good thing was the pay….but what is your soul worth?
cons:
Worst management I have ever worked for because:

1) Management lied about the hours expected from you: was told that overtime was occasional on job interview to find that overtime in needed every day to get the amount of work done that they dump on you!


2) Wasn’t told in interview that there are NO raises unless you get promoted (see #6 about promotions). So you could be the best at your job and go the extra mile only to be told, “Good Job, maybe you’ll see a Bonus” (if the private equity firm allows it.)

3) The most often words I heard from Management were: “I can’t speak to that.” or “that’s beyond my scope”

4) Never worked somewhere before where I was told by management to NOT help people outside our department.

5) Even though our corporate handbook had windows of times for business hours to be at work, I was told by management to be in early every day, and then was given the stink eye for leaving a 5.

6) Was told by senior management that I could not be promoted because I didn’t have enough “sweat equity”. I was told that I do my job the best of anyone who has had my position before, but I would need to also do the job of the position I wanted for at least a year or two before I would get the title, not to mention doing my job also. That’s right, I was told that I would have to do the work of 2 people and not be paid for it until one or two years into the future.

7) Senior management would put any issues you present to them on your project list for you to correct. This would include following up with their peers, instead of them doing it themselves doing their millions of meeting. I swear the meetings were so they could hide from work and responsibilities.

8) Never worked with so many people that were in finance that had NO finance background. I guess that is the talent you are stuck with when you lay off tons of people and have a policy to NOT rehire any one that used to work for the company. I worked with Finance people that majored in History, Politics and Psychology. NO JOKE, the $5B divisional CFO was a person from a treasury department who needed “working capital” explained to him every month during cash flow meetings. 

9) Management hires “Management Trainings” to get them coffee, schedule their meetings and post positive reviews on websites (like Glassdoor) instead of doing any real work!

10) NO Team environment.

11) Told if I wanted to keep my job, I’d have to move from Pittsburgh to Chicago with no change in salary for cost of living.

Conclusion: The company and people there are all jokes and phonies. I’m actually embarrassed I worked for this company and this is what’s wrong with America. Thanks to you: Warren Buffet and your Brazilian Death Squad, which is the killer of American Jobs and Iconic Brands. Hope you all are proud of yourselves!!!!!!!!!
Advice to Management
Lead the company instead of hiding in meetings that don’t produce results. Stop killing American Jobs and understand that profits are not the only thing that makes America Great. Being productive and contributing to society means more!!!!!!
Helpful (32
advice_to_mgmt: Lead the company instead of hiding in meetings that don’t produce results. Stop killing American Jobs and understand that profits are not the only thing that makes America Great. Being productive and contributing to society means more!!!!!!

pros: The only pro is getting your foot in the door for a supervisor position. Complete your 2 years if you can.
cons:
Current labor is hideous. Employee moral suck. Supervisor attitudes suck. Upper management leads by intimidation, bullying and fear. This company, under current "leadership" treats every single person as a commodity. Hourly employees can be forced 12 hours up to 1 minute of their shift being over. Attendance is a joke, I believe 17% daily due to calling in. Because of this, forcing for overtime is a nessecity to keep up with demands. A lot of mechanical failures plague operations. This can be contributed to the nonexistent preventative maintenance programs exercised. USDA turns a blind eye to the "holesomeness" of the product and the "sanitary conditions" of raw production. I give anyone a 50% chance of making it 6 months there. if you show up to work with a pulse, everyday, you will have guaranteed employment at this facility. Daily, you will hear everyone talk about how much they hate coming to work, hate the company, hate everything. It is literally a joke, please think twice before accepting a position here. I can't stress enough the severity in this review, I am holding back much more, as I'm sure others restrained as well. Good luck.
Advice to Management
my advice is for the directors and VP's, you must open your eyes and clean house at this facility. Start with SSE, then IL6S, then quality and finally the pious manufacturing manager. Do this, in this exact order.

review_title: New Company, New Vision, New Culture! Good Kraft Foods is gone
pros: Worked at Kraft Foods for 13 years. Great Brands, lot of talented people, lot of opportunities to grow, good place to start your career and learn.
cons:
Financial drive company with a new vision. 3G's aggressive cost savings target has put too much pressure on the organization. Work life balance is gone, is about how many hours a week you can work. Teamwork is not part of the culture, is about the numbers. Few resources to sustain current business, due to unrealistic cost efficient goals. Expect more changes over the next year or so, until they buy another company. It was a hostile takeover (not a merger), lost too much experience by cutting Kraft Employees and having Heinz leadership lead the company.
Advice to Management
America's favorite cheese will lose consumers in the marketplace, by not being competitive. The formula of High prices in commodity driven categories will open the door for competition. It will take a while for Heinz managers to understand key Kraft drivers. Act fast, modify your strategy and support your employees. They are valuable!

employee_status: Customer Category Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Well established company with a rich history of brands that give you a seat at the customer table. Plenty of support resources for information, marketing, business planning and strategy. There are still some legacy Kraft employees that care about the people that work for the company.
cons:
Owned by an investment company that only cares about bottom line profit and not people, actual business strategy, or workload. Cutting cost is priority #1, which has resulted the loss of jobs for thousands of people. Workloads are ever increasing and support is declining. They are also pinching expenses and something as simple as a team lunch, car wash for company car, interest service for home office are all out of pocket expenses. You will fell overwhelmed with work and under-appreciated working for the new Kraft Heinz Company.
Advice to Management
Begin to think of your employees more personally and consider their lives and commitment to the company. It seems to be very easy to let people go just to cut cost and increase profit without considering an individuals years of service and commitment to Kraft Heinz. You need to appreciate everyone that works for you and consider other company strategies other than bottom line profit for stock holders. You are effecting people lives with you decisions.

Advice to Management

★★★★★
Current Employee - N/A in Pittsburgh, PA

Negative Outlook
No opinion of CEO
I have been working at Kraft Heinz Company full-time for more than a year
Pros
-Working for a top CPG company with well-known brands
-Exposure to leadership
-Friendly co-workers
-Dual headquarters located in Chicago and Pittsburgh, which are two great cities to live in
-For some the amount of responsibility given to even junior-level people can be a pro
Cons
-Constant change in people, leadership, & processes that cause an insane amount of waste, re-work, lack of resources, and onboarding
-Extreme cost cutting has hurt employee benefits, the company culture, and the overall success that Kraft Heinz can achieve with its products
-Due to the constant changes and heavy cost cutting, work/life balance is a struggle for many employees
-Value of meritocracy is not followed, as most people end up being promoted only because their boss quit or was let go
-Furthermore, many workers are either promoted without a sufficient pay raise and some are not promoted, but just take on another person's job without a pay increase
-Little acknowledgment of a job well done from leadership
-Always a fear among employees that they will be laid off
-A very weak support and training system for newer employees
-Crazy tight deadlines with budget cuts and limited resources that make completing most projects on time impossible
-Too many meetings at times that take away from in-market impact and actions

Overall, a very poor culture has been created in which most employees are very negative about the work they do and their job. I would say at least 70% of my co-workers I talk to are actively looking to move to another company. Kraft Heinz is certainly not a great company to work for at this point in time.
Advice to Management
The 3G model is to cut inefficient costs and make the organization as lean as possible, but leadership has cut too heavily, driving fantastic employees out. But it is hard to give advice to management when they have done this at many other companies, and it has worked at least from an EBITDA perspective. Management's drive to be as profitable as possible has ruined the culture and work/life balance at Kraft Heinz.

pros: Pre-June 2013, I loved my job. I was a valued member of the team, made positive & meaningful contributions to the business, and our input was sought after in order to make decisions as a group. The people were wonderful, bright, and experienced. Company policies and systems worked almost flawlessly. None of that was left when I left....it's a sad display of corporate greed and a chaotic, miserable mess. Inexperience reigns....it's exactly what they had in mind though, so I guess they consider it a success. Biggest pro for me: I'm not there!
cons:
Post-Destruction of an Iconic brand: Layoffs followed by taking on the jobs of 2/3 people, policy changes without employees' input by people who barely spoke English let alone understood how things worked in reality. No concern for their customers' businesses. Saving millions of dollars looks great on paper, but the mess it leaves in its wake is true and utter destruction. Chaos was an understatement. Employees are seen as a means to an end....don't dare question what they want you to do...just do it or you'll have 3 angry Brazilians standing behind you at your cafeteria-style table speaking Portuguese to each other saying who knows what. 

Some tips if this sounds like the place for you: 

*Don't leave your desk to go to the restroom or lunch....eat at your desk so they see you working, otherwise prepare to explain where you were....or they may just call you on your cell phone to track you down. 

*Keep working until you see your manager leaving (probably at 7 or 8pm) Meritocracy!!! You will get rewarded for your hard work.....in your dreams. In reality, they will just hold off on hiring an employee for those 3 other people that quit....you will get their jobs too! It's ok though, because they've pared your job down to something a well-trained monkey could do. 

*No need to worry about those pesky customers, half the time, there won't be any product to ship or nobody will seem to know where that product ended up....it might be there sitting on the dock....or it may have never even been produced....nobody seems to know.
Advice to Management
I'm amazed that there is even a business left. Kudos to you on the great success of your deception of the American consumer. As for me though, I have and will forever support your direct competition. Thank you for making my departure so wonderfully sweet....I was able to enjoy the sunshine and my work for the first time since you took over. Keep following your Big Dream and just wait for the day that your karma comes back around.

pros: Big company with known brands.
cons:
All 3G cares about is cost-cutting. 

Leadership preaches “meritocracy,” but the reality is that if you are well paid because of years of hard work & and top-rated performance, your history does not matter; your job will be eliminated. Leadership has no problem cutting high potential, high performing employees in lieu of inexperienced, lesser paid employees. Conversely, mediocre performers are kept if their compensation is low relative to peers. “Meritocracy” is a farce, and 3G’s flippant use of this word makes my blood boil. 

Those left at Kraft Heinz are working around the clock. Inexperienced 3G cronies are leading without a clue on process, creating inefficiencies in the work force. For a management team that preaches "creating efficiency", they place zero value on human capital efficiency. Perhaps compensation should be hourly (i.e., variable cost) to force 3G/Kraft Heinz leadership to actually think about efficiency in the broader sense of the word.

This merger was a “no win” for any Kraft employee, unless you were one of the top executives who pocketed millions due to Golden Parachutes. Those left at Kraft Heinz are working double time for the same or marginally higher pay. Those laid-off are in a job market that is saturated with top Kraft talent. Yes, severance packages were great, but as someone who actually wants to work, I’m mourning the loss of a company and job that is no longer. 
I grew up in a country where hard work is supposed to be rewarded – the definition of capitalism. What I’ve learned is that the rewards from years of hard work can abruptly come to an end when wealthy foreign investors make short-term decisions to pad their wallets. It’s sad that 3G can continue to buy and steamroll American companies, eliminating thousands and thousands of jobs without regard to peoples’ livelihoods. 

I couldn’t think of worse people to work for.
Advice to Management
Start focusing on more than cost cutting. Your nothing without people to run your company.
Helpful (19
advice_to_mgmt: Start focusing on more than cost cutting. Your nothing without people to run your company.

review_title: Once proud to say I work at Kraft.... No longer the case
pros: The original Kraft Foods Company hired great people, and we all felt a common bond of being part of something great.
cons:
Poor culture since the merger of Heinz and Kraft. 19 year employee that took pride in working hard for results and pride in who I worked for. Sad to say that is not the case any longer. I would not recommend the new KraftHeinz to a family or friend who is looking to start a career. No longer a place about its employees, or work life balance. As I mentioned before, I enjoyed working hard for the results of my business. To the tune of 60-65 hours a week. Working thru vacations or time off, because I felt ownership and pride in my sales results. That is no longer the case. One could work 80 hours a week and never feel you are accomplishing anything. Employee cut backs, moving service (administrative, finance) work to India, closing plants is not the proud Kraft Company I was hired by. If a 1/2 star rating was available, that would be my rating for the New Kraft Heinz Company. 

Do yourself and your family a favor, look elsewhere when beginning your career. If you would be proud to work for Bernardo Hess and Kraft Heinz, who let go of employees within 24 hours of being notified, who spent 15-42 years with a company, then this company is for you.
