pros: literally none. Maybe some other departments will have one good thing or two, but finance depart is a total night mare.
cons:
If there is a reward for the most ridiculous company of the century, it will have to go to Heinz without discussion. Heinz is absolutely the worst of the worst among all companies I've known of. My words are strong but sadly they are just the truth.

First of all, this company shows absolutely no respect to its employees. It doesn't care about you being a human being or having a personal life - your privacy means nothing to the leadership, meaning that they will ask for your number and hunt you down no matter what time it is and no matter what you are doing - on the toilet or giving birth in a hospital. Who cares? Just send me the excel in the next 20 mins. Your privacy and human rights are being invaded with a seemingly justified reason - we have a tight deadline. How about hiring more people instead of making one person do three people's jobs? Hours are bad, although personally I don't really struggle with being stuck for working long hours. However it does make you feel less enthusiastic when the leadership takes it for granted and never shows a bit of appreciation. 

Second of all, there is literally no culture or whatsoever here. The HR will tell you it's highly collaborative and supportive here, while the fact is you often have to spend 80% of your time on a daily basis chasing after people for data/materials, or sending emails to mangers/directors asking for information but being ignored. There are no training for new recruits, which is fine. But the majority of people only care about their own job routines and are extremely indifferent in teaching or helping, and it could really make things difficult for you.

Third, the company is so frugal that I have to write a book about it someday and sell it on amazon. There is only water and tea in the kitchen - not even ketchup. OK fine it is no big deal. Then you soon realize that you have to bring your own pens and paper for work because there is no office supplies. Well can still deal with it. How about cutting your bonus because the leadership keeps adjusting up the EBITDA target that there is absolutely no way to hit? Sometimes I wonder, do they really not know the incapability to hit the lines they set up? My guess is that they do know, but there is a better way to save the spending in people compensation - cutting bonuses by setting up a high internal target that the company is certainly going to miss. So convenient. 

Forth, a great amount of time at work is wasted because the company has a very poor data management system. Numbers aren't tied across different database, mappings are often in chaos, and there are often a lot of manual dirty work going on behind the scenes that causes the inconsistency between your numbers and mine. If you graduate from a top school and have high expectation of what you will be learning at work, please avoid here just the sake of this one - you will be spending most of your time trying to solve issues that can be easily avoided by having a better IT system. You aren't learning anything real.

Overall all the negative feedback you are seeing here - from me or others - are true. And I do think it's inevitable having 3G as the management. They just want to get rich - that's what Private Equity do. They are not here to plant tomatoes. While the stock price of food companies often stays very stable and has a very low beta, 3G's tactic here is definitely not to reap profits by boosting up the business itself. With very aggressive cost cutting (zero base budgeting), it is very much easier to boost up the bottom line while maintain the stock price at a decent level. After a few years? Of course the business suffers. But it will be probably time for them to transfer ownership already.

Make your own judgement. But Heinz is rated 2.0 here. The lowest score on Glassdoor is 1.7. if you join Heinz, one day you might be able to write a review such as this one and contribute to making Heinz literally the worst company on Glassdoor.

What's the point having this section? Maybe I'll fill this out one day in future when I come up with new jokes to mock how great it is to work at Heinz.

pros: Since the merger in July 2015, there are no pros. They took away every single employee perk and benefit in the name of cost reductions via Zero Based Budgeting

3G capital buys a new company every 3 years, guts it to look good on paper, then continues on like locusts leaving the remaining companies losing in the background. It's like a global ponzi scheme, and eventually, it will fall. I made it through the merger firings but will be quitting ASAP because nobody should have to be "Thankful you have a job" if you're qualified and have a history of documented success. review_title: Ex employee who was let go 2 years ago
pros: Since takeover on June 6, 2013 - there are no pros other than being able to list well known Heinz on resume. I was one of the very luckiest ones to be let go first. THANK YOU 3 G and Warren Buffett. I do appreciate VERY MUCH!
cons:
All the negative reviews are the true reviews. If you believe the planted positive reviews and want to believe them - go work there and you will find out there are no positive reasons to work there there than a paycheck. Benefits have been taken away in these past two years and am almost positive that any additional benefits will never be added. Out of the original 800 plus Pittsburgh employees who used to work there prior to the take over - only about 60 to 80 of those people still working there. I heard of 600 jobs but less than 10 percent of those are the original employees. Now with the buyout of Kraft - I will be shocked if these jobs in Pittsburgh will be kept.
Advice to Management
As your sales continue to plummet - you should have thought about all those Heinz past employees and their families who won't be buying your products (and also not buying your Kraft products or even Burger King.) We former employees will never forget how you have changed our lives. Even though we are glad to be out of your harnesses - we do remember the old real H J Heinz Company that was a true American icon. It wasn't the perfect place to work but when compared to you - it rated so high that even 5 stars would be enough, You only keep the Heinz name because no one would buy your true name of 3 G or Warren Buffet Ketchup. Be advised that we all know you don't have any of the real Heinz values especially "to do the common thing uncommonly well." Your only idea is profit and more profit but keep in mind that when you keep changing your products by using less quality products - people will taste the difference. Than your sales will continue to drop even more. Our only hope in the U.S. is that companies like you go under and go home so you can't destroy any other home grown American companies. Hopefully you won't listen to this advice and you will be the cause of your own demise. Remember that Americans are much smarter than you believe and spending our money wisely is something we all want to do. Too bad for your company that Heinz and Kraft are no longer the American icons they USED to be. Go home and build your own companies up so you can't destroy any other American companies!!!!

review_title: Used to be great. 3G will take their cash and decimate what's left.
pros: There are no more pros to working at Kraft Heinz. There used to be...I worked at the former Kraft Foods for over 15 years and loved it. Great pay, great benefits, great work-life balance, great development and advancement opportunities. The environment began to change after the company split in 2013 towards a more high stress environment and the words "move faster!" were so overused that we became deaf to it. It was still tolerable...I would not have left. Enter 3G....and now we move on to the "
cons:
section of this review.
Cons
3G is transforming Kraft to a completely different company, and not in a good way. Look at the 3G history. Read the books. They come in, cut costs to the bone, work people to death, have a heavy hand and a dictatorial style, all for the slimmest of hopes that *you* might be one of the lucky ones to get a big bonus. In actuality, if you read reviews and talk to employees from Heinz, Burger King, and Anheuser Busch (yes, 3G owns them all), only a small percentage of people at the top truly benefit from the so-called "meritocracy". I left voluntarily and am so relieved as I watch the newest reviews coming in. I feel so bad for my friends who remain with the company. Keep up your strength and keep your resume up to date.
Advice to Management
Open your eyes. See what you're doing. Putting inexperienced kids in charge of big business has a cost that is greater than the benefit of fresh ideas that you won't even put into place unless they line your pockets. Experience really does matter in big business. Be honest about what you're really trying to achieve...cost cuts to make the business profitable, and when that no longer works, you buy another company to do the same thing. You're in over your head in a lot of matters at Kraft. You don't understand the complexity of making a large organization successful, so you use your tired formula to make money and run the company into the ground. Recognize it, say it out loud and stop being so arrogant.

review_title: Talks the talk but doesn’t walk the walk
pros:
To be perfectly honest there are none. 

Heinz was once a fine company and one that I was proud to work for; however, 3G Capital has changed all that.
cons:
Let's start with layoffs, buyouts, early retirements, "voluntary resignations", plant closures, etc. to prune the workforce down to a combination of young (read lesser paid employees) and those who either lack the motivation, education or skills to succeed elsewhere. 

Tenured employees who didn't leave and were formerly not considered for promotion now find themselves stars in management positions without the wherewithal to succeed. 

Next is the lack of work/life balance. Since staff has been cut and one person is now doing the work of many, with no direction or support from management, the result is chaos-induced-stress and long hours. 

Add to that importing cronies from Brazil, who lack the necessary skills to run the company for long-term success and the future is not bright. Can they cut costs and show short-term profit? You betcha!! It's hard to say how long Wall Street will listen to excuses though.

Be wary of positive and glowing reviews as they appear to be "planted" to offset the truth.
Advice to Management
Why bother as the situation has reached a point of no return.

pros: The company is VERY disciplined and is doing what it said it would do and what it believes is necessary to deliver best in class financial results. This makes it very uncomfortable for everyone familiar with "conventional" practices, even those that remain. Every cost element is scrutinized. Definitely not suitable to all.
cons:
To any conventional organizational employee, the company has become stingier. There is an expectation of longer hours and a big increase in workload. Over the coming month, it will become clearer which work items really weren't that important to do. KHC doesn't really value institutional knowledge. Their belief is that good people will learn.
Advice to Management
Really only one - you should calibrate on what communicating openly, and often means. You've already demonstrated you're in charge. Why not share the new org charts and save us from asking half a dozen people who we should be working with.
Helpful (2

review_title: The Devil is Winning so far
pros: Kraft -not KraftHeinz - was a great place to work with normal office politics. Morale was good and you could develop a good career.
cons:
KraftHeinz is a complete train wreck. If I hear "meritocracy in action" one more time I will need to self harm if only to feel a new kind of pain. It is clear that Bernardo and his fellow Brazilians (all men of course) knows nothing about the CPG world as he can barely speak English. He is embarrassing to watch. The manic laugh is particularly disturbing. The layoffs were brutal. If there was a litmus test for basic human decency the 3Gers would fail utterly. They let key leaders with great knowledge and leadership go and have now left only young and clueless in charge. They don't care about innovation and have absolutely no vision/strategy except to work endless hours....on what I'm sure I don't know. I was shopping online in my last days as nothing could get done and if you wanted to pay a vendor you nearly had to write a personal check! I believe in Karma and they will get what they deserve but thousands will suffer in the mean time. Sad to say but true....getting let go was the best thing that happened to me. Strange to think I live in a world where I stress out over keeping my job vs getting laid off. It would have been nothing but misery and suffering if they had kept me. Happy to be gone and good riddance.
Advice to Management
None. They don't care. Enjoy your millions.
Helpful (19
advice_to_mgmt: None. They don't care. Enjoy your millions.

pros: Learning ZBB application, great products and legacy Kraft Foods' employees working together & supporting each other through these challenging times.
cons:
No autonomy, no strategy, no process, no respect for employees or vendors, no communication and no diversity. Not a true meritocracy as claimed, rather they place employees in roles they are not interested in and hold them to undefined goals with no support to get there. Hard to not think we are in some social science experiment or reality TV series.
Advice to Management
Respect people, listen, be humble and value diversity of thought. ZBB is a tool not a strategy!

pros: Top notch people in other departments and in plants.
cons:
My department was very emotionally abusive toward introverted individuals. This behavior was tolerated and even encouraged by management. Director stated that quiet people were not "whole".

Lots of emphasis on attending after hours happy hours, etc. It was expected that your work mates would become your family and the majority of your free time would be spent with them.. 

The quality of work that a person accomplished seemed to count for nothing. It was all about how out going you were.

Lots of mean girls at this company. And they rise to the top.

The concept of individual differences is totally foreign to these people.
Advice to Management
Grow up and become emotionally mature. Everyone has something to contribute. Discriminating on the basis of personality, although legal, is just childish.
Helpfu

pros: Hours are 8-4:30. This is actually the only pro. If you work at the Innovation Center, you don't have to pay for parking.
cons:
Customer service management is a joke. They micromanage, don't even know how to use SAP or what our job is. People that get promoted are also jokes.. Very immature, have no experience, more concerned with going out and drinking than their actual job. The so-called 15% bonus we were told we would get when we were hired turned out to be a whopping $700, which is not even a paycheck. There have been no raises for people that have stayed in the same position for at least 3 years. Management also expects you to stay late to work, some people staying until 9pm during our SAP conversion, yet not even a thank you, bonus, or raise. I would not recommend this company to anyone. Save yourself the misery.
Advice to Management
Reevaluate your management. Most of customer service is quitting because of management. Also there have been no incentives for anyone to stay with the lack of raises. People have been trying to move out of customer service for a year, yet management does not help. I would not use one of my current managers as a reference ever.

review_title: A good company destroyed by insipid capitalists
pros: Can't think of any pros for the new company. Old Kraft was a really good place to work. Great Work-life balance, Employee career development, very talented and collaborative teams to work with. Goal oriented, strategic business planning and investment in employees and business partners.
cons:
Absolutely no value to talent, didn't put any efforts to preserve institutional knowledge. Don't anticipate any growth for this company. Hardly any innovation is going to come from KHC in upcoming years, if any, they will keep maintaining their current brands. With half of the talent and most of the valuable senior and most knowledgeable people gone, very intrigued to see what's next.
Advice to Management
Heinz's product portfolio is quiet different than Kraft's. While Heinz had quiet a few self stable and/or frozen products, Kraft has much diverse portfolio including refrigerated and room temp products. The same tactics that worked for Heinz 3 years back very likely won't work in KraftHeinz.
Helpful (11
advice_to_mgmt: Heinz's product portfolio is quiet different than Kraft's. While Heinz had quiet a few self stable and/or frozen products, Kraft has much diverse portfolio including refrigerated and room temp products. The same tactics that worked for Heinz 3 years back very likely won't work in KraftHeinz.

pros:
Fast-paced environment. Roles and assignments always changing
Getting hammered by management builds camaraderie within teams
cons:
- Entire culture is a lie and a ploy to get employees to give up all work-life balance and competitive compensation and accept unreasonable demands, while they dangle fake "meritocracy" as a carrot
- All career advancement depends on politics
- Heinz and now Kraft are being run into the ground by upper management which doesnt know what it is doing (all came from a railroad company). Anyone can just fire people indiscriminately, but it takes someone who knows what they are doing to make smart cost cuts where it wont hurt future growth prospects. Just look at their top line results.

PS: Many of these positive reviews are clearly written by HR, which is just pathetic.
Advice to Management
They certainly dont need my advice. The top 10 people in the company as well as 3G/Berkshire Hathaway are making a killing by destroying the company. Once they are done, they will move on to the next one. The model works for them (and makes them very rich) but doesnt work for the employees.
